I would LOVE to be able to recommend this, but I can't...
After endless hours on PS4 and another 91 hours on PC, I just gave up in the end.

The biggest issue - like any Rockstar game - are the Cheaters/Modders.
You can spend ages gathering supplies say for Trader, build up a good supply, start a mission, only to then have your supply yoinked in the blink of an eye and sold by someone else. As annoying as it would be, I'd of been fine if it were stolen and sold by actual players playing the game, but what are you supposed to do against someone who can legitimately just teleport your supply away?
Then comes the classic ones from GTA - such as planting infinite explosives/Fire Bottles at your feet, teleporting you to the top of the skybox to plummet to your death, disarm you of everything you own (Weapons, equipment, supplies, etc.), and of course (As mentioned above) disrupting missions.

Then when it comes to getting games without a Modder, the next problem is that RDO is much better with Friends - there's a better chance at playing the game and getting missions done when you have a Posse formed. On your own (Like any Rockstar game again), you just get completely wrecked, and I've found RDO Posse's to be far more relentless than GTAO Players. GTAO I might have someone kill me a few times for about 5-10 minutes before they move on... RDO: 1-2 hours. Like, holy hell; it gets to a point where I just AFK and wait to see how long before they move on: 2.5 hours is the record so far.
It's all part of the game, I get it - but if you're a low level, a new player, or returning player; then good luck trying to survive solo against a Posse who have everything unlocked from Gold Bar purchases and can just spam explosive & incendiary ammunition.
The game is much better with Friends. GTAO at least there is some fun with playing solo - RDO; not a chance.

However; in my opinion, this game could of been very easily redeemed had Rockstar not given up on it so quickly. 
So many unique ideas could of been added (Heists as an example), but instead it was just grindy missions & roles that offer little to no fun. The only fun this offers is if playing with friends and just goofing around, otherwise it isn't worth it.
Very disappointing Rockstar pushed this aside to focus on GTA - so much promise, yet so little care.

Red Dead Online, the multiplayer component of the critically acclaimed Red Dead Redemption 2, is a game that truly captures the essence of the wild west. The game’s expansive and meticulously detailed world, combined with its immersive gameplay, provides a unique and engaging experience that is hard to match.

The game’s strength lies in its stunning open-world environment. The beautifully crafted landscapes, the dynamic weather system, and the diverse wildlife all contribute to a sense of realism that few games can rival. The attention to detail in every aspect of the game, from the character design to the intricate storyline, is truly commendable.

However, it’s disheartening to see such a beautiful world feel somewhat abandoned. The lack of substantial updates and new content has left the game feeling stagnant. The potential for more immersive storylines, engaging missions, and innovative features seems to have been overlooked.

Despite this, the game still offers a lot to its players. The freedom to explore the vast open world, engage in various activities, and interact with other players provides endless hours of entertainment. The game’s complex character customization and progression system also adds depth to the gameplay, allowing players to truly make their characters their own.

In conclusion, while Red Dead Online may feel like a beautiful world that’s been left behind, it still holds a lot of charm. It’s a game that offers a unique and immersive experience, and despite its shortcomings, it’s definitely worth exploring. Here’s hoping the developers will breathe new life into this beautiful world in the future. 🤠

SPOILER FREE REVIEW:
Despite it saying red dead online, I ended up playing red dead 2 on the launcher. My initial thoughts back in 2020 of this game were horrible, as I was a sweaty no life fortnite loser who couldn't appreciate games. I revisited rdr2 recently, and I completely replayed the game. I even got the high honor ending (the better one). The game was nothing short of an extreme masterpiece. The vast world that rdr2 was able to captivate, along with the world that rockstar created for us is breathtaking. The fact that this game that released in 2018 looks better than most recent games is proof that rockstar is a magical gaming company. This video game is a masterpiece, and a 10/10 overall. The story is amazing, the visuals are amazing, there's plenty of missions and dialogue to go through so you never get bored, and even the epilogue was one of the best parts of the game. Playing as Arthur was a magical journey, and he is currently my 2nd favorite protagonist oat. Rdr2 is a game every gamer should try, even if you don't like story games. If you don't have the time, watch a playthrough with 0 commentary. No matter what, you should play this game or at least consume the media thrown at you.

Pros:

Stunning world: Rockstar's meticulous attention to detail shines through, creating a visually breathtaking and atmospheric world to explore.
Deep character customization: Craft your unique outlaw with extensive character creation options, including clothing, physical features, and even morals.
Variety of activities: From classic cowboy pursuits like hunting and fishing to story missions, robberies, and showdowns, there's always something to do.
Evolving world: Rockstar regularly adds new content, missions, roles, and gameplay features, keeping the experience fresh.
Poignant world-building: While primarily focused on action, the game touches on themes of morality, societal change, and the fading frontier, adding depth to the experience.
Cons:

Grindy progression: Earning money and experience can feel slow, especially early on, hindering access to desired items and roles.
Microtransactions: While not pay-to-win, microtransactions for gold bars can accelerate progress, potentially creating an uneven playing field.
Griefer issues: Open-world PvP can sometimes lead to frustrating encounters with disruptive players, although defensive measures are available.
Technical hiccups: Occasional bugs and connection issues can disrupt the gameplay experience.
Content gaps: While updates are regular, there can be periods with less frequent content drops, leading to a feeling of stagnation.
Overall:

Red Dead Online offers a unique and captivating online experience in a meticulously crafted world. However, the significant grind, potential for disruptive players, and occasional technical issues can be drawbacks. If you're patient, enjoy exploring a vast and detailed world, and can manage expectations, Red Dead Online can be a rewarding and immersive experience. But be prepared for some frustrations along the way.

[h1] Why you should or should not play Red Dead Redemption 2 (Story and Online) [/h1]

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2915561463

[b] What is Red Dead Redemption? [/b]

Rdr2 is a open world (story or online) game. In the story mode you play as a interesting man called Arthur Morgan and you go around trying to help your gang while meeting new friends on the way and adventuring through the gorgeous open world. There is plenty of things you can do whether it is through the story mode or the online mode. Online is a little different then the story however, and you can meet other players in the game and talk to them through the open mic feature. There are many different types of enemies in the game (in online that can be other players). There is bounty hunting, horse taming, stealing, animal hunting and much more within this rich story line. This game is also based in 1899 if I remember correctly, so, no telephones have even been invented yet. 

[b] Initial Thoughts: [/b]

-"What a beautiful open world, wheres my horse I want my horse."
-"Can I kill this lady? WHOOPS, OH GOD, RUNN"
-"OH GOD OH NO WHY ME WHYY"

[b] Beginner Player Friendly?  [/b]

This game seems pretty beginner player ready, though online is not as friendly and a lot of murder does happen. The only thing is I never really understood the controls to well, they can be a bit confusing at first and you may need to check your keyboard or controller binds. Yes this game is controller compatible so that is always a nice addition to this game as well. There is a map that helps you navigate your way though if you want, you can just wing it and figure it out on the way.

[b] Game Play: [/b]

Once you get the hang of the controls you can kind of understand whats happening and how to work the game. There is loads of character customization and you can continue to edit your character throughout the game. In story mode though you cannot edit the character himself, you can only pick and choose what clothes you decide to wear on the character. This game has the option to have either a first person or third person view of your character, I favour the third person view a lot more then the first person because the first person view gives me motion sickness. They have many different features you can unlock throughout the game's story and you do the objectives of whichever NPC in order to get paid and progress further in the game. This goes for both online and the story mode. The story has more content then online does, however online has more player with player and PVP options that make it more interesting. Everyone plays this game differently, and its up to you how you want to make your adventure and what ending you will get. 

[b] Graphics: [/b]

This games graphics are absolutely gorgeous, though as of recently I have been noticing that a lot of them have been broken. My map, horse textures and skin textures have all been breaking. Which is probably because Rockstar has been working on other games as of recently. But I did notice a patch update so I hope that helps fix some of the problems. This game has some of the most realistic graphics and world textures I have ever seen, and it makes me appreciate them a lot even though sometimes they break. For some people I would recommend turning down the graphics as they can be super heavy on your gaming device. Sometimes my computer breaths like a air turbine even though I try to keep my graphics on medium. Thankfully my computer still doesn't lag and doesn't get too hot. There have been games that have pushed my PC further then this. 

[b] Community: [/b]

The community is a mic of, crazy people, role players, bounty hunters and toxic players. After a certain level however I have noticed that they aren't as intense. Some of the toxic players (which are not as common as they are in say, CSGO) do make very inappropriate and some times too far jokes. However the large majority of the community are pretty hilarious and I have met some absolutely AMAZING people on here. Some in which are going to read this review and tell me how cringe I am. The other people you have to look out for on this game are the modders, some are awesome. I am friends with some of them! As for others... They are extremely toxic and irritable. Though usually if you switch servers when you see flaming horse feet, you are pretty okay to avoid them all together. But again, the large majority of them are amazing people and are willing to help you out if you need and offer you some good laughs. 

[b] How long can you play? [/b]

The game's playability depends on how much you like it. I am only 5 hours into the story mode and I am still at the beginning of it, so if you are here for the story it is 1000% worth it and you can play it for hours on end. As for online, if you are only there for the content and not for the players then you will be able to have quite a while to play and sometimes it can be a bit slow paced. But if you are there to play with other people, you will end up like me and have quite a bit of time in the game because you want to hang out with your friends and be absolutely psychotic.

[b] My Opinion: [/b]

Overall I recommend this game if you enjoy story games (for the single player story mode option) or if you really enjoy hanging out with your friends and being forces of nature. I would also say if you enjoy just strolling around a beautiful world on horse back, this could be an enjoyable game for you.

[i] Any major edits that are made with this review will be added here: [/i]

*This review has been posted on both the online and the story mode versions of the game*

This game isn't really supposed to be GTA Wild West. It's a really nice idea of the Old West that's spoiled by the likes of bears, wolves and a lot of soppy paying cunts instagibbing you whilst you spawn, ride at speed on a trail, or merely hang around for more than three seconds, and you can do nothing to stop them other than paying to prevent them doing so. The difference between this and "modern" GTA is that you can do as you please in the future world, whereas in this one the devs seem to have bowed to a lot of twats who sit and wait for players to turn up before killing them. "Ooh, but that's how the game works" say those players. However it comes as a disappointment when the game shows itself to be a balanced one because of the setting. A sad mess, and not worth the time and effort unless you are prepared to pay a lot to win.

More than 2 days later and re-install after latest update 31 January 2024 and it is no longer crashing.  The update caused a problem with launching RDR2, so I re-installed both steam and RDR2 - all problems gone!!!

The phrase "This game is literally unplayable" has become a meme, but most certainly true for Red Dead Online. 
For most people, you cannot play for more than 10-15mins before being kicked or crashed by one of the many cheaters/modders that plague this game. Sometimes you'll play for a little longer, sometimes you'll get crashed within the first 30 seconds.
Don't get me wrong, the game has been very fun and relaxing in the past. But that's not what it's like now. Whenever you load up the game, there will be at least 2 or 3 cheaters/modders in every lobby. They will crash you, they will spawn stuff on/around you, they will make the game unstable. It's like trying to play Garry's Mod, but it's set over 100 years ago.
Red Dead Redemption2/Online will go down in history as the most expensive abandoning of a game, you can bet your sweet dollar that Rockstar has gone and is not coming back. 
I have enough hours in this game to tell you that it used to be good, but as a warning to any new players, don't buy it. Not until Rockstar fixes this horrendous problem of cheaters and unstable servers, if that ever happens.

Dont get me wrong, this is a fantastic game. But it has been overrun by cheaters and griefers. They will harass you in game and if they really don't like you, your IP address is completely open to them and they can follow you off the game and try to continue the harassment there. Worst of all, you don't have to go looking for the cheaters, they are in plane sight, they advertise themselves with big flashy names. You don't even need an anti cheat system. Sad to say, some of the players that harassed me, who have been reported are still playing. There are youtube videos of them harassing other players. This seems to go months on end. The game should not be for sale. You are putting yourself at risk by playing it. Years later the cheaters are still playing and i can no longer play the game. They have my IP address and they kick me from the game as soon as i come on. Shame on you Rockstar.

Don't usually leave reviews...however, this game is frustrating enough for me to do it.

First off, it's a buggy, slow-loading mess.

Second, you can only play the story missions through matchmaking. There are so few players in the lobby that you rarely match with anyone. And if you do and they randomly leave the mission, your mission automatically fails. Rinse and repeat your waste of time.

Until they let you play the story gates solo, I won't be playing this game.

Slaves

Literally the best game ever. This game is ridiculously good and I don't care who you are. I have a very high level character on Xbox with basically everything unlocked, but I was looking for a good PC game to play with my friend. We couldn't figure out anything to play that was any good that we hadn't done already. But then I noticed this was 10 bucks on Steam. I just shrugged and asked "Red Dead Online?", and when he texted me back he already downloaded it. Wasn't really too excited, but hey, I had already had thousands of hours of fun on it on Xbox, so why not? I bought it too after he told me he got it. As you might be able to tell, I haven't worked in awhile LOL... 112 Hours at the time of this review, and it hasn't even been two weeks LMAO.... I'm freaking addicted. I played over 30 hours in one session. Haha... This shiz is just so much fun. I'm level 45 on PC now and I only just recently purchased the game. It's the best co-op experience, the most fun gunplay, crazy good immersion, addicting repeatable missions, and a super slow burn as far as leveling up and gaining things - which I LOVE in a game as long as it is fun to play. There is just so much to do... Fishing, hunting, bounties, story missions, PVP, Running a Moonshine business.... The list goes on and on... Sometimes I like to role-play as a serial killer, and stealthily murder people in towns at night. You can get into slap fights in your moonshine bar. You can rope somebody and hogtie them and then they are at your mercy. Stab em to death, burn em alive, throw em in the water and feed em to the gators... Haha.... Just ridiculously well made! The MINOR TINY bugs compared to other games are so rare they are basically non-existent. The graphics are MINDBLOWING. The gunplay is weighty and realistic. If you don't like this game, then you most likely have had some issues with griefers and modders. I can't really divulge any information for you, but if you really want to avoid them - Google is your friend. ;) Can I just say that 10 bucks is a freaking steal for such a great game? :D

Hello fellow gunslingers.. This is Annie Wilde with an update on how this game runs. It's honestly a great game to have fun with friends or solo. It's like GTA 5, has many things you can do to pass the time. From trading, specialties, tasks, missions, racing, horseback riding in the wilderness, hunting wild animals (including legendary), Meeting other players, crazy npc and random moments. It's really a good lay out and I've enjoyed it. The only THING I WOULD RECOMMEND is get the file that allows you to play solo or with friends. The actual servers have hackers and some are mean as hell. They will want to make you rage quit the game. Get the file, add it to your data folders and play peacefully. Unless you like chaos then have at it. I've enjoyed the game with the ultimate edition and also play the storyline of Arthur Morgan. The humor in this game is great too. I'm also an author of fanfictions so it's helping create an adventure in a novel (Which will be posted on Wattpad one day).

This game would be great if it didn't crash every 5 minutes. Rockstar has yet to update the game, and I doubt they will as they've abandoned it for GTAO. Specialized roles are completely broken; trader and bounty hunter will either crash your game or just not load anything, if you're lucky. Free Roam Events are the highlight of this game--a great way to make money and interact with more than just hackers. Error code #FFFFFF and straight up crashes without warning or error message will kill any desire to grind, which is unfortunately a lot of this game. It's beautiful and has the potential to be great, but hackers really ruin the fun, and Rockstar enables them by not enforcing anything or installing protective measures for other players. 
*Have fun trying to report any hackers, it will just crash your game every time.  ;-)

**Update (1/19/24)**

I can't in good conscience recommend the online mode to anyone while it's in its current state. Back in 2020, perhaps even early 2023, I did, but not now!

Modders have made RDO almost impossible to enjoy.

It used to be just having to change servers once modders would drop several bears or cougars on me, I could get away from them for a time and still enjoy the game. Now, they'll track you down and blow you/your horse up, they'll make your game crash, and even if you were to avoid towns and just focus on roles for the leisure of it they've enabled some kind of coding that gives you an infinitely looping loading screen!

There's almost no one else in these servers except griefers and cheaters, it's not a fun experience anymore.

I'm at the point now where I'm thinking about uninstalling RDO and sticking exclusively to the main game until something is done to stop this. 

Rockstar has pretty much abandoned this feature and it shows, and it's VERY ugly.

I won't ever buy another Rockstar game unless it's proven for a fact that they've learned from this disaster and decided to get their act together and promise to place and maintain firm protections in future titles.

Please, do yourself a favor and avoid playing online for the time being, it'll save you a massive headache and disappointment. There isn't even much of a chance to grind now.

++++


I really wish I could give a neutral recommendation for this review, since it's not the quality of the game I'm really basing this on, it's the user base and the in-game price inflation. But, oh well.


I already enjoyed playing RDR2 on console and was thrilled to be able to play with some of my PC friends.

It's a beautiful, tranquil, and immersive experience. I really play it just to ride a cool horse, go fishing, and cook over a campfire. 

Until I came to realize that Rockstar has little to no protective measures in place to sieve out the irritating players from the casual ones. 

I do enjoy playing online, don't get me wrong, but there are a number of issues that interfere with the quality of gameplay and I strongly suggest that you buy this game on discount ($20? No, and you'll understand why in just a moment) AND be sure to either have higher level friends help you get through the first fourteen rank levels to unlock basic gear such as the fishing rod, or, get lucky and find nice players at random to join up with.

This is NOT a game you will want to play on your own on PC, cheaters have more free reign here than ever before on console, so things will be a bit messy for starters.


Some things you can expect when booting up the game includes:

*Hackers have found ways to make online a slog by either spawning deadly animals on top of players or creating spontaneous explosions that disrupt gameplay. In either case, players often need to exit to menu and log back in to change servers and enjoy the game without hiccups. Rockstar has no protections in place to prevent cheating of this sort, just as a warning.

*Griefers apparently have nothing better to do once they reach max level and unlock all features of the game; they have no problems hunting players down and ruining a good time regardless if you're simply wandering in free roam or taking part in a friendly competition. Even worse, if you were to try and report them Rockstar will do nothing - no temp. bans, not switching the servers for you, nothing.
But, hey, most of them don't even speak so you usually won't have to worry about age-old slurs being lobbed your way. Yay? I guess when your character dies you can opt to Parley and give yourself ten minutes of invincibility, boring the trolls just long enough for them to turn around and find someone else to bully. So, there is that as a saving grace, sort of.

*Micro-transactions are a big part of online mode; either you pay real-world cash for in-game gold bars to buy stuff more easily (5 gold bars versus $500 for a shirt. I am serious here.) or you can grind. And grind. And grind, oh, did I mention that you gotta pay 15 gold bars for almost all the major career options in the game before you can get started on ranking up and collecting rewards? (Bounty Hunter, Collector, Moonshiner..cool sounding jobs, right? Well, you better get that gold first so you can buy the licenses/kit bags!) I hate micro-transactions as a principle since that is a very slick slope into financial anxiety. 

While this game is beautiful and usually enjoyable, when I can get those moments of peace, it leaves one wondering if it's even worth playing if it's so easy to get blown up, shot at, get turned into a rag doll, lose your hard-earned profits while traveling with your Trader cart as it gets blown to pieces...

You can grow to like RDR online, but do NOT take it seriously, and play in short bursts if possible.
And don't give Rockstar any more of your money than they deserve. Don't buy the gold bars. Ever.

[b] Abandon Wear [/b]

[u] The main game is amazing, but RDR2 Online is a cesspool of hackers and bugs. [/u]

- RP is extremely limited due to the state of the game
- Griefing is encouraged via Daily Challenges & new players don't stand a chance
- Constant Crashes & Insanely Long Load Times
- In-game Economy is Garbage $150 for a hat +$1000 for a pouch
- Trade & Moonshine Runs fail during Loading wasting invested Time and Mats
- Reporting Hackers does Nothing, [b] the game is no longer monitored! [/b]

[b] - Unchecked Hackers with God-Mode [/b]
 - Hackers can add the Rockstar Admin logo to their names
 - Hackers spawn infinite money, gold & gear bypassing level restrictions
 - Hackers set their level, hostility, and status to whatever they want
 - Hackers teleport anywhere they want on the map
 - Hackers can teleport everyone on a server to one spot, to be slaughtered
 - Hackers send self-guided explosive barrels that land on your head
 - Hackers spawn 50 hostile animal around you, just for LoLs
 - Hackers summon UFOs with death rays in a western game
 - Hackers turn random NPCs & Animals into flame throwers
 - Hackers kill Quest Givers & NPC needed for Quests for hours at a time
 - Hackers ignore Parley and Camp No-PvP Flags 
 - Some hackers have found a way to pirate Steam account through the game. [i] (When you accept gold, killing a spawn, or harvesting a spawned corpse) [/i] You are literally risking your account and payment information by playing RDR2 Online.

The abandon nature of this game, the countless security holes, and game destroying bugs are both an embarrassment & reflection on the management within Rockstar Games. [b] [i] They would be far better off if they figure out a coop mode for the main story line and left it at that. [/i] [/b]

Title: "Red Dead Frustration: Where Cowboys and Cheaters Square Off!"

Howdy, fellow virtual cowpokes! Get ready for a rollercoaster ride through the pixelated plains of Red Dead Redemption 2 Online – a game where the wild west is filled with laughter, tears, and more cheaters than a crooked poker game in a dusty saloon.

Let me paint you a bleak picture of the frontier: you're saddling up with your posse, ready to ride into the sunset for an epic cattle rustlin' adventure. But hold your horses! There's always that one varmint who thinks he's the quickdraw sheriff of the server, armed with hacks that'd make a snake oil salesman blush. I reckon the good folks at Rockstar Games might want to reconsider calling it a "Red Dead Redemption" and instead name it "Red Dead Respawn."

Now, if you enjoy a good ol' fashioned round of disconnection roulette, then Red Dead Online is the place for you! Every ten minutes, like clockwork, the game closes faster than a saloon door in a sandstorm. It's like trying to build a house of cards in a tornado – frustrating, futile, and downright infuriating.

Imagine this: you're about to complete a mission, pockets full of loot, and the thrill of victory within reach. But suddenly, the screen goes black, and you find yourself staring at your desktop like a bewildered tumbleweed. It's a true test of patience, my friends, and let me tell ya, it's more difficult than trying to lasso a greased pig at the county fair.

In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 Online is a virtual wasteland where the only constant is the relentless onslaught of cheaters and the game's uncanny ability to crash faster than a lead balloon. So, saddle up if you dare, but be prepared for a frustrating journey through a wild west that's less "rootin' tootin'" and more "Ctrl+Alt+Delete." Yeehaw, and may your disconnects be swift and merciful.

This game is fantastic to play with friends, not so fun when playing on your own or with randoms, as communication makes life so much easier in the game.

I'm sure there are a lot of good reasons to play this game (you can easily read up anywhere) but here are a few things to keep in mind though:
The economy in online is not the greatest, I suppose that's a way for people to grind missions and play a lot more. E.g. horses will understandably be expensive, but things like accessories, clothes and low-level guns are too expensive given how much you earn in missions.

There's a weird system where you gain more XP, Money and (sometimes) Gold if you take longer to complete missions. A lot of the time (even when playing solo) these missions only take 5 minutes max to complete, including travelling time, yet a timer of 15-20 mins is given.
You just end up running the time to the last minute, spending 10-15 mins foraging, hunting or collecting etc. Just to earn you the extra RDO$10 and 0.2 Gold Bars, 

There are a number of activities to do in Free Roam and more game modes available with friends, however they can become very repetitive and even boring if you've done them multiple times already.

Unfortunately, as of now, Rockstar are no longer adding any DLCs or updates to the game. So really cool aspects from RDR2 (Story Mode) like heists and train robberies aren't a thing Online, the closest to those are the Opportunities, via Blood-Money Missions. Even then you have to do a few Blood-Money Missions that earn you Capitale (a form of currency that allows you to do Opportunities) all for more or less the same pay-out as any other mission in the game.

"Is it worth it"

I would love to give this game a positive review and a thumbs up but I can not in good conscience do so, so here are the events that led to this negative review, enjoy. 

I boot up the game,
I spawn in,
I call my horse,
I stow my weapons,
I look at the days challenges,
I see that there is one for skinning four coyotes,
There are three coyotes in front of me, lucky me,
I kill two with the third coyote escaping,
I ride over by the pelts,
I skin one of them and stow the pelt on my horse,
Me and my horse are blown up,
During my respawn time I look at the players in the session,
There is a level 333 player with every letter of their name a different color,
I click on their RS name and I block them as I do with all cheaters,
Their RS name does not match their in game name (common cheater thing they do),
I spawn in and blow up again,
This time it lets me press charges against rainbow name doesn't match 333 person,

I've played RDR2O for over 671 hours and my opinion of the game is based solely on the Online as I've never played the Story Mode, I love this game in fact the only game that is better in my book is a whole series of games and even then it is very close, I'm level 198 with again over 671 hours the fact that I've suffered through this game simply because I love it shows just how good of a game it is and how good it could be if RS would simply do anything at all to stop the cheaters, now for the third time I've played over 671 hours of this game and in all that time the longest I've ever gone without running into a cheater was maybe, maybe one hour most times its within twenty to thirty minutes at best and at worst go back and read the first part of this review again.

There is also a difficulty Curve for players using a Keyboard and players using a Controller as Controller users can lock onto enemies, animals and other players this means that players on Keyboard are at a great disadvantage as they need to be far better skilled with aiming then their Controller counterparts, I'll note that players on Controllers still show a great deal of personal skill but that Keyboard users are not given any assistance or at the very least very, very little assistance if any, in the end this means that I as a Keyboard user must be faster and more accurate then a Controller user if I am ever going to win a PVP encounter. 

RS has also been banning people that haven't done anything while somehow still missing the people flying around as 20 foot hawks so that's fun, RS doesn't care about anything but Money.

I want to give this game a positive review but I simply can not the game is broken not because of bad code or a game ending bug but because RS does not give a single solitary thought about the players that play and love their game, RS sits back and watches as cheaters destroy their game, and that's before you look at the fact that the cheaters are even stealing In Game Gold which could be considered real world money destroying the games economy for other real players, then there's the time that they waste from the real players I'd wager that about 100 of those over 671 hours was spent running from session to session so i can actually play the game, in all you've got a broken game so do not buy this game unless you are willing to suffer through the cheaters and trust me you will suffer at their hands time and time again until RS does something about it, RS please do something do anything please do anything and help us real players, and when you do I'll be overjoyed to change this review to what the game should be getting.

So in closing you must be asking yourself "Is it worth it?"

Red Dead Online Review: A Dynamic Frontier of Possibilities

Red Dead Online, the multiplayer component of Red Dead Redemption 2 developed by Rockstar Games, offers a vast and immersive multiplayer experience set in the sweeping landscapes of the American Wild West.

Strengths:

Expansive Open World: Just like its single-player counterpart, Red Dead Online presents players with a breathtaking open-world to explore. From the bustling towns to the serene wilderness, the attention to detail creates an atmospheric and living frontier.

Dynamic Activities: The game features a variety of dynamic activities, from intense shootouts to more leisurely pastimes like poker or fishing. This diversity allows players to shape their own experiences and engage in activities that suit their playstyle.

Robust Character Customization: Red Dead Online offers a robust character creation system, allowing players to tailor their avatars to their liking. The ability to acquire new outfits, gear, and customize your horse enhances the personalization aspect.

Weaknesses:

Economic Balancing: Some players have raised concerns about the in-game economy, suggesting that certain items and upgrades may require a significant time investment. Finding the right balance between progression and accessibility could enhance the overall experience.

Occasional Technical Issues: Like many online games, Red Dead Online is not immune to occasional technical hiccups, such as server disruptions or bugs. While Rockstar continues to address these issues, they can temporarily impact gameplay.

Engaging Multiplayer Features:

Posse Dynamics: The posse system encourages cooperative play, allowing friends or other players to form groups and tackle challenges together, adding a layer of camaraderie to the Wild West experience.

Role-Playing Elements: The introduction of roles, such as Bounty Hunter or Trader, adds depth to the multiplayer experience. Players can specialize in different roles, each offering unique missions and rewards, contributing to the overall depth of the game.

Conclusion:

Red Dead Online successfully extends the captivating world of Red Dead Redemption 2 into the multiplayer realm. With its vast open world, dynamic activities, and engaging multiplayer features, it provides an immersive Wild West experience that continues to evolve.

Something needs to be done about the modder/hacker problem or else GTA VI is a no-buy on PC. Clearly they don't prioritize their PC releases, but this game and GTA online on PC are downright unsafe to play. Your account is legitimately at risk of being taken over by a hacker, and yeah this is possible in other games, but the problem is so bad in RDO that you cannot find a single lobby without a modder. A lot of players resort to playing in glitched private sessions, but that kind of defeats the whole purpose. 

Otherwise, it's an unfinished and unsupported multiplayer mode that should only be bought if you're really into the old western theme. If you're not, it can be incredibly boring and seem like there's no real point to any of it, other than a pointless role grind to unlock clothing and weapon skins. My character is over 100 levels and there's nothing more for me to do that is enjoyable. I've completed all of the roles, grinded collector for thousands of dollars, got most of the trapper clothing items and have done every heist. (my playtime on steam doesn't reflect that, most of my time was spent on the Rockstar games launcher client.) It was a little better when they had an active battlepass-type system, which allowed you to even earn back the currency you used to buy into it. They don't do that anymore. In fact, this game is lucky to receive any updates at all anymore.

Runs surprisingly well on Steam Deck, with some minor graphical errors noticed. Overall, looks great and performance is decent.

As an avid player of Rockstar Games, I was excited to try out Red Dead Online. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint. I have been playing it for a few weeks now, and I have to say, it is pretty solid.

First of all, the graphics are stunning. The details of the open world are mind-blowing, from the landscapes to the smallest details like the way the horses move. It truly feels like you are in the Wild West. The attention to detail is impeccable, just like in any other Rockstar game.

The gameplay is smooth and immersive. The missions and activities available in Red Dead Online are diverse and keep you entertained. From hunting and fishing to robbing trains and completing story missions, there is always something to do. And the best part is, you can do all of this with your friends. The online aspect adds a whole new level of fun to the game.

The character customization is also impressive. You can create a unique character with different hairstyles, clothing, and accessories. There are also different abilities to choose from, which adds a strategic element to the game.

One of the best things about Red Dead Online is the open-world PVP. It is intense and exciting, especially when you team up with your friends to take down other players. The online community is also friendly and welcoming, which adds to the overall experience.

However, the game is not without its flaws. The economy can be a little unbalanced, making it difficult to earn money and purchase items. But I believe Rockstar will address this issue in future updates.

In conclusion, Red Dead Online is a solid game that offers a vast, immersive open world, fun gameplay, and an active online community. It is the perfect game to play while waiting for GTA VI, and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys open-world games. I cannot wait to see what Rockstar has in store for us in the future.

[i] The only "Labour of Love" is the effort that hackers and cheaters go through to make the game completely unplayable and labour for the nominee who actually deserved it. [/i]

Firstly, Rockstar is very aware of the incredulous issues with this game and have done absolutely [i] nothing [/i] about it since its inception. As a matter of fact, in early [i] 2022, [/i] they had given up entirely on supporting Online, being generous enough to leave it running to continue sales, but there's no love for the community in this regard. For example, there are hackers who bypass the PvE option -- which itself is VERY poorly implemented and turns off automatically -- hackers who have you explode the second you log-in and with every spawn, forcing you to quit the game; and the list goes on and on. Any bug that is present will remain. 

There's no doubt that Rockstar is one of the best developers, with one fantastic hit after another, and do put an enormous amount of love into their games -- probably due to crunch -- and [i] Red Dead Redemption 2 [/i] being one of the best games in years, but the general disregard for PC players with every title and their online components shouldn't be excused.

The "Labour of Love" that Steam has just awarded them is an insult to the actual nominees and should immediately be [i] revoked. [/i] The fact that it qualified in the first place is utterly baffling and should have been blacklisted from voting. The votes themselves were [i] satire [/i] and has made a laughing stock of the voters. The winner gets the last laugh with the physical award that'll be on their desk, rather than a developer who actually deserved recognition for their work this year. Developers will never learn.
"Labor of Love 2023" The year I lost faith in gamers. No wonder the industry does what it does... no wonder.

Red Dead Online has been absolutely dead in the water for over two years. There are no updates, there are no fixes, it is complete radio silence and abandonware. The hackers and cheaters have become so brazen as to be able to publicly imitate Rockstar themselves in lobbies with zero visible consequences. It is a tossup and a gamble whether any event will just be crashed by some wannabe comedian playing dropbears on everybody involved, and they have all powers, including being able to ban you nearly at will. 

The idea that anything involving RDR2 or RDO at this point in the good year 2024 is a labor of any amount of ongoing love is a face, ridiculous, and I wish a temporary but excessively annoying and itchy rash upon the sensitive regions of the people who believe otherwise. Rockstar *could* work to make RDO and RDR2 still relevant, but they don't, too busy on GTA6.

I loved playing this game on Xbox when it first came out and the online dropped about a month after if I recall and even though there wasn't much to do it was still a real treat to hangout with friends in this world that offered me so much joy and admiration. However fast forward to the PC release and the last "real" update the game got and I cant say in good conscience to buy this game. Rockstar has completely abandoned this game a couple of years ago and especially today the game is overrun by a load of glitches, cheaters literally everywhere, and a myriad of server problems. We had some really good updates over the years but now there is no reason to play and even if your like me and just want to experience what is already there you can't. I do not over exaggerate when I say that Red Dead Online is completely UNPLAYABLE, missions don't start no matter how many times you reset or change sessions, ALL PVP MODES are impossible to play with rampant cheaters everywhere, the game crashes all the damn time, micro transactions are way too pay to win and can be used to bypass almost all forms of progression, and if that wasn't bad enough there is no solo sessions that I could find to circumvent some of these issues. Don't buy this game, and to Rockstar I am unbelievably disappointed and fairly angry that you let something this near and dear to my heart be turned into this garbage. If you really cared about your players you would do the bare minimum and fix the problems that this game has (cheaters, bots, glitches, bugs, server problems, stability, etc) and let players experience what is already here until the sun sets on this game. You should be ashamed of yourself for letting this game be put down when it was just getting good. Thanks for reading this fairly long and ranting review of my favorite online experience i've ever played.

I don't give a damn about losing any other mission, I can get most back, but I can't get his. This game has infuriated me beyond belief, but it is LUCKY my friend makes it worth while. First off, I must say something about this game.  It is absolutely beautiful and fun to play!  However, it is plagued by modders and hackers that will harass you for the 'luls' while yelling racial slurs at you in voice chat.  Not only that they will also try to bait you into looting spawned boxes in front of your character to get modded money so you yourself could get banned.

There is no way to escape the hackers/modders.  Some have even made it into a phased mission to ruin the game for you even further.  Some hackers/modders have a system set up that when you report them you are kicked from the game when sending in the report.

At this point, beginning to wonder if Rockstar Games will ever do something to beef up their security.  For now I'm going to continue to play the game while biting the tips of my fingers off when a hacker/modder ruins my gaming activity for it's on a daily basis at this point.

The game is awesome, HOWEVER

RDO PC has been overrun by "hackers" and script players, making it often unplayable. 

In the short time I've played RDO I've seen every manner of "hacked" madness you can imagine (players spawned as UFOs, sharks with shotgun mouths just blasting innocent players, swarms of legendary creatures in town, entire constructed buildings/stage sets, "purge" npcs who attack on sight, forcing you to fight for your life thus earning a bounty for murder, etc etc)

had my moonshine shack hacked so that I blew up the moment I stepped out of the bar

had my name hacked so that there were two copies of me in a lobby, while the other "me" killed & blew up every player in sight (I'm expecting a ban for that anytime, I'm sure they will ban me and not whoever did it) 

on top of all of this, if a lobby is "hacked" the stables won't work, the moonshine shack won't work, missions wont load properly, etc so you're often forced to reload to find a good lobby, and the game crashes constantly, too. 

and now Rockstar is banning innocent accounts while these blockheads run rampant and continue to make the game a nightmare for the rest of us. I paid for the game and have bought gold for the game and would continue to do so if I thought it was worth the investment, but this is a sh*tshow and Rockstar is a joke for how they're (not) handling it.

edit: the crashes are not due to system requirements

windows 10
ryzen 5 cpu
36gb ddr3 ram
rtx 4060 8gb ddr4

second edit: as my playtime is likely to suggest, none of this is enough to stop me playing the game 😅 so take that as you will, of course! RDO is very fun (especially with friends and family) if you have the patience for the "full experience" in online play

Red Dead Redemption 2 redefines the very essence of gaming, transporting you to an evocative world that feels alive with its stunning attention to detail and immersive storytelling.

Set against the backdrop of the dying Wild West, this game is a cinematic marvel. The graphics are a testament to the craft of the developers, painting landscapes that are as breathtaking as they are hauntingly beautiful. From the sprawling plains to the rugged mountains, every inch of this meticulously crafted world feels authentic and alive.

But it’s not just about the visuals; it's the depth of the narrative that truly captivates. You step into the worn boots of Arthur Morgan, a complex protagonist navigating a changing world. The characters around you feel real, each with their own stories and motivations that interweave to create a rich tapestry of emotions and experiences.

The level of immersion is unparalleled. Whether you're hunting legendary animals, engaging in intense gunfights, or simply bonding with your trusty steed, every moment feels purposeful and contributes to the larger, immersive experience.

Moreover, the attention to detail extends beyond the main storyline. The dynamic ecosystem, the changing weather, and the interactions with the world around you create an environment that responds to your actions, making every decision impactful and shaping your own unique journey through this unforgiving yet captivating world.

In essence, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of gaming. It's not just a game; it's an epic odyssey that invites you to lose yourself in its vastness, to explore its intricacies, and to experience a world that will linger in your thoughts long after you've put down the controller.

Alright, listen up, boah. I know your brain might be as slow as a three-legged mule, but let me spell it out for you: Red Dead Online is the best thing since sliced bread, and if you can't see that, you're dumber than a bag of hammers. Now, unlike your feeble intellect, Red Dead Online has more depth than a puddle after a drizzle. It's got everything – from stunning landscapes that probably make your simple mind implode to missions that require more strategic thinking than a game of checkers with a toddler.

But let's not forget the real kicker, boah. The online community is thriving, unlike your social life. You can team up with other players, form posses, and maybe, just maybe, experience a sense of camaraderie you've never felt before. But hey, if that's too much for your tiny brain to handle, stick to playing with your imaginary friends.

Red Dead Online is a masterpiece, and if you can't appreciate it, you're probably the type who thinks a tumbleweed is a sophisticated form of entertainment. So saddle up, boah, or better yet, stick to playing marbles – it might be more your speed.

Red Dead Online for PC has more game-breaking bugs than any game I have ever played in my life. As someone who loves the single-player mode of this game, it is astonishing to see a product this broken come from Rockstar. If your experience is anything like mine, you will have to manually quit the game every hour or so due to some glitch or another. Walk into a stable to buy horse gear and the menu doesn't appear, unable to exit the stable--restart the game. Try to start a supply run for your trading business, locked in conversation with Cripps with no menu popup--restart the game. Complete a full delivery of moonshine, no cash credited--restart the game, still not credited. I can't believe I spent money on this garbage, and I find it even more baffling that this is a Rockstar product. It's a blight on the entire company. And that's to say nothing of what a letdown the experience is even when it works, due to the prohibitively expensive in-game economy. And nothing of the rampant cheating/exploiting ubiquitous in almost every lobby. Such a letdown.

Where do i start

I really want to like this game, and honestly i do like it, but i don't like what rockstar has done with it in recent years. We haven't gotten a major update in 2 years now, and rockstar uses the "excuse" that they are transfering all their resources over to developing GTA 6.

But guess what? GTA online gets updates and new storyline missions/heists virtually every month, despite it being a game that's over ten years old.  Meanwhile Red dead online doesn't even have basic matchmaking for telegram missions, you have to manually create a posse and invite people on the server in the hopes of them joining you. (you get a limited amount of invites too that refresh after a couple of minutes) There's no text chat unlike in GTA online, so most people don't even know what you're inviting them to your posse for.

As if that all wasn't bad enough, the game is outright infested with Chinese players who all have mod menus and will grief everyone they find. I would say around 75% of the playerbase is chinese currently and without fail they almost all will use mod menus just to blow you up and use godmode in competitive game modes. Rockstar doesn't even acknowledge that these players exist and just like with GTA online, rockstar has completely given up on punishing hackers/mod menu users.

At the bottom of it all is a good game that has been utterly failed by Rockstar as a company and it's been torn to scraps by Chinese "players" who aren't good enough at the game in the first place so they rely on mod menus to compensate for their lack of skill and intelligence. The game crashes quite frequently due to modders and inherent rockstar server instability. You'll also get a lot of permanent loading screens that require you to restart your game.

 The irony is that this game had the potential (and arguably still does have that potential) to be an even better cash cow for rockstar than GTA online could ever hope to be, and be significantly more enjoyable to play than GTA online at the same time. Good job rockstar.

Written after playing for 30 hours
------------------------------------
I'm a person that bought the game to play mainly with other players. The game world is beautiful (if you're computer is powerful enough), full of animals, landscapes and adventures to explore.

Most of my playtime goes towards exploring the game and earning gold bars to purchase the bounty hunter license. My reasoning for doing this is to be able to customize my character with weapons and costumes before trying out the pvp, and then settling for the pvp in the long run. I wish I tried the pvp thoroughly first instead of trusting that it would be as entertaining as I envisioned.

When joining the different pvp series such as the shootout series there are a couple of things to note.
First of all the loading time and matchmaking is tedious, it can take 10 minutes to start a match. On times of the day with less active player it can take longer.
Instead of showing the player a browser window with the various games available, how many players there are in that game and letting you pick one, you will blindly be loading for about 5 minutes to maybe find the match you are looking for.

When writing "maybe find the match you are looking for" I mean that there are different types of games even within each series. For example in the shootout series one is a free-for-all, another is a team deathmatch, and some games are entirely different and force a predetermined loadout on you, instead of letting you use your own loadout you strived to achieve with your in-game grinding, or bought with real life money.

If you're fortunate and enter the match you're interested in, you'll quickly notice that the majority of players use the auto aiming system to their advantage. When playing pve against other npc's I can see how dead eye and auto aiming can be entertaining for some, however in pvp it completely eliminates the aspect of having to aim.
If you miss a shot with a rifle while standing 100m away from your target free aiming, a person with the lock-on aim can instantly turn around, lock on to your torso and tilt the aim slightly up to most of the time one-shot head shot you (most of the time because of ability cards), all this while sprinting. 
Players with enough in-game dollars or gold can also buy the most powerful tonics that make them live many more shots than other players that lack these tonics.

You could then say, but what about the hardcore game mode? In this game mode the ability cards, tonics and the lock-on aim are all disabled. 
You'd be right, however there is still the element of having to dress up and use completely different setups from the one you select before the game starts. In one team you may be assigned a top hat, while in the other you are assigned another hat. And as mentioned before some games even give you an entirely different weapon loadout than the one chosen by you prematurely. It's as if Rockstar is giving the player a freedom to customize their character in free roam, however this freedom is trampled on in online matchmaking.
On top of this there are less players playing the hardcore games, so it's even rarer to find a match in this series compared to the shootout series.

Loading in the different maps takes a while as well. Even if it's because all the assets and other game elements need to be loaded in, is it worth it? Is it so important that all these small crates, coffee mugs or detailed chairs are loaded in, when a match lasts for about 10 minutes and my focus is on staying alive or finding other players? When searching online I can see that the loading times are an issue in games such as GTA V as well.
Battlefield 4 loads up quicker and is in some aspects even more aesthetically pleasing to look at with destruction etc compared to Read Dead Online.

This is the first Rockstar game I purchase, I doubt I'll buy any other Rockstar title. There are simply too many other competitors that have solved the lack of performance compatability that Rockstar keeps repeating across triple A titles.

Other than that the game offers variety, from fishing to hunting and trading for players that are interested in this. The dialogues and cinematics in the game are well made with great voice acting, but there should be an option to skip them as they can be lengthy.


Written after playing for 423 hours
-------------------------------------
I've played an additional 393 hours of this game now, because I enjoy some of the core mechanics such as the combat (Except the ability "Paint it Black") and the looks of the game. 
However, I still stand firm on my first impression of the game, and would like to add that the support and respect the staff of Rockstar has for their players is minimal. The game is riddled with hackers and Rockstar either lacks a full fledged way to detect them, or let them roam the game.

When writing "lacks a full fledged way" I'm referring to a technique Rockstar uses to detect hackers, which involves the earning of massive amounts of gold in a short period. However, many players have been banned or suspended this way claiming that they have never hacked.

Rockstar also updates their newswire every month on their webpage. However, this month (December 2023) such an update has yet to be posted. I hope the company continue to support Read Dead Online even though they release new games such as Grand Theft Auto VI.

the singleplayer is one of the best things I've ever played. the multiplayer is dogshit abandonware that bans legitimate players for even being in the same lobby as a modder, and rockstar is doing absolutely nothing about it. won't accept appeals or respond outside of automated messages.

This game is abandon ware at this point. The only way to play without being accosted by hackers is to play in private lobbies, which ruins the entire point of this being an online game.

I've had a lot of fun with this game over the years I've played it, but I can't in good conscience recommend anyone buy or play this game now. Rockstar Games abandoned admitted they abandoned the game years ago, and they won't be developing new content. That's unfortunate, but the actual nail in the coffin for this negative review comes because of the recent ban wave they're doing. Innocent players are getting banned left and right--with no ability to review and appeal the ban--because other players are modding the game and griefing. It's happened to several of my friends, and they've lost hundreds of hours of work and things they bought with real world money without any option to get it back. For the crime of... accidentally being put in a lobby with someone they don't know who is cheating. 

If you're going to abandon a game, that's fine. Leave it in it's buggy, near unplayable, cheater-lousy state for those of us who still wanted to enjoy as much as we could. But mass banning innocent players as a 'solution' when the actual rule breakers get off scot-free? I'd rather never play again and hope I get to keep all my progress than never play again and have lost it, thanks.

To be straight up, if you're here for soaking in the atmosphere and the stunning world of this game, you've hit the jackpot. But if you're looking for ongoing adventures, well, it's a bumpy road ahead. Rockstar Games seems to have moved on from this game pretty swiftly after its release. Here's the kicker: in terms of content updates over the past couple of years, the community's gotten zilch.

Their focus seems to have shifted to the bottom line, echoing the cash-hungry trend of many other big corporations. Yeah, their single-player experience was top-notch, but when it comes to Red Dead Online, it's been lacking compared to the single-player masterpiece. It's just a downer to witness a company that once valued its community seemingly lose touch.

I originally left quite a positive review on this game. But, after my recent encounter and bs with Rockstar, I'm changing my review to a negative one.

I, recently was playing the online, and I usually play by myself and I don't really play with any friends or anything like that. I was minding my business, and I think I encountered a hacker or a modder of some kind. Kept killing me blah blah blah the usual nonsense they try. Only reason I can confirm they were exploiting is when I tried to kill them, they wouldn't die and take no damage at all.

Anyhow, eventually I managed to get away from them and go back to what I was doing. An hour later, I get booted from game claiming I've been suspended. So I check my email, and I get an email claiming I'm suspended for a month and my character will be reset etc. Mind you, I don't mod, cheat, nor hack in this game. After doing some research, I see several other people were caught in a suspension or ban wave this month around the same time as me. So, I don't think it's a coincidence at all.

What I don't appreciate is Rockstar unfairly doing this. Then, claiming I can't dispute and suspensions/bans are final even though I haven't exploited this game at all. So, after dealing with this, I'm taking back my postive review and don't recommend this game. Also, Rockstar has stopped all support for this so they have no cares for it. Neither should you.

Wish this game was better. Here's some things to improve upon it.

- this should've been bundled with RDR2 instead of it being an entirely separate purchase.
- the gold system is crazy, some things can cost upwards of 100 gold. keep in mind 25 gold is 10 dollars. you can argue "you can get gold through missions." while you are correct getting .01 gold every hour or so just isn't worth the grind. 
- the money system. having weapons and clothes be upwards of 500 in-game dollars but only paying out 20 dollars per mission or 27 cents from dead bodies just makes the game harder to play as a new player.
- Modders running rampant. The amount of times I've had my game crashed or being imprisoned because I shot at someone in god mod is insane. Riding around from town to town and having 1000 legendary bears spawned on me makes the game impossible to enjoy.
-  The modder issue wouldnt be so horrible if you could make solo lobbies. but oh wait, you cant! you're forced to either play in a session while being harassed by 3 modders, or install sketchy software to make private servers, or do 40 random steps that just lead to you turning off your internet for 10 seconds.

Use startup meta or you will crash 24/7, hackers ruined the game.

Everyone wondering why your crashing?
The issue is that you are with a Hacker in a lobby.
There is a guide how to get rid of the crashes i will link it down below.

The game is great and runs like a dream but as soon as a hacker is in your lobby you will crash.
And even animals stop spawning or npcs that completely disappear.

All because of hackers...

This is a necessary fix, get the latest runtime zip:
https://vulkan.lunarg.com/sdk/home#sdk/downloadConfirm/latest/windows/vulkan-runtime.exe

Second get this just to make sure:
https://www.techpowerup.com/download/visual-c-redistributable-runtime-package-all-in-one/

last but not least go to your Local Appdata and delete your DXCache that is in your NVIDIA folder.

The very last step is to get the legal screen script:
https://www.nexusmods.com/reddeadredemption2/mods/28

Go to your steamapps\common\Red Dead Redemption 2\x64\data
And put the file in the data folder.
This file will start your game in a solo session.

If you wanna play with your friends make sure to use the same password in the startup meta file.
All you gotta do is put a password at the bottom of the file and your done there are guides online how to do that.

And suprise suprise no more crashes, all the npcs are still on the map and no more smart people that fly across the map.

I played more than 4 hrs in a session without crashing.

I cannot speak for the direct online community/experience as I've only played it privately with my spouse. But with that, I absolutely recommend it to anyone looking for a cool and cozy game set in the wild west. You can play through high or low honor and that will adjust how the world responds to you. I love the care for horses and the hunting aspect, and some of the little achievements are funny. 

What I don't like is that it lacks a few things the main game has. You can't tame wild horses even if you have an open stall...that was a huge part I loved in the main game that isn't even allowed despite the tutorial saying you can. I wish that posse members could donate toward camp improvements easier than needing to give up opening a treasure chest or giving perfect hunts to support...just a QOL thing. 

In the case of gold, initially I was peeved you couldn't get any job titles or some things without gold, it seemed like you really needed to spend money on the game. However, through gameplay we've found that you can get some amount of gold for the randomly generated assist quests in the world (such as giving a traveler a ride into town, etc), and you can get good gold through some free roam quests, purple world events (some events you need more than 2 people, but not many), and you can get gold through treasure maps. 

Overall we really enjoy the game. Wish we could use some rdr2 mods to give it some extra fun, but alas it's good enough where it stands now. You can also upload photos you take with your camera in game to the social club for R* and then download them from there if you want.

If you want a game like GTA Online, go play GTA Online. If you want a game that hasn't been whole heartedly abandoned by one of the world leading AAA developers, go play GTA Online.
This game is dead, you can play it, you can enjoy it, and If you are here looking for that cowboy experience, welcome. But there will never be any new content past what we already have. The online story mode hasn't even been completed, it was just abandoned half way though. Sadly, there is no other game like this. 
Maybe if GTA Online dies and everyone stops playing it, maybe then they will take the raw potential of RDO and make it a real, full and interesting MMO. But right now, most people will play it for maybe 30 hours and never come back. 
Don't buy RDO though, buy the RDR2, as that is worth being called the greatest game of all time and almost makes it feel like this wasn't made by a money hungry machine that overworks it's staff and rips off it's fans and players.

Reviewing this game separately from the single-player campaign, your enjoyment depends on a few factors:

1. If you liked the main story sections of the single-player campaign.
2. Enjoyed hunting, treasure hunts, and managing a camp/business.
3. Found bounties fun.

The online version not only includes these but expands on them in detail. With 5 major choices, each with rich stories and missions, it surpasses GTA Online

Minor server bugs occur roughly every 20 hours. One joyous discovery was a posse invite leading to a hidden 'Speak Easy,' a surprisingly fun experience.

Worth the investment, but a 4/5 due to minor bugs, cheaters and unclear game sections.

It is a fun game to play alone or with friends. And if you're outgoing you can even make friends here in voice chat. I like how immersive this game can be. Though I like this game, still, I'm not too fond of two things. For one the stables, I along with friends constantly get stuck in the stables and we have to completely close the game and restart it to get out. Another thing is the number of modders, while some modders are nice others aren't and it gets annoying dealing with the mean ones. While yes, I can switch sessions sometimes I have to switch sessions a lot of times before I get a normal server with either none or nice modders. That aside if you can pay attention to the story and do missions it is overall a great game. If you do not want to encounter modders I would suggest buying rdr2 (solo game) not online but if you want to play with friends online is your only option.

As others have said, the griefers and modders make the game basically unplayable in [I]public[/I] lobbies. You will be teleported away from what ever you were doing at random times, killed repeatedly by people you can't even see, and be subjected to immersion breaking things like UFO's, unnaturally large creatures, and weirdly sized or colored players. However, if you learn how to do a private lobby using a text file, the game is glorious! I play this way with a friend, and while I miss the interaction with other decent people (they exist!), I  never have to worry about random disconnects or being griefed while I enjoy the stunning landscapes and just going about my business in the game world. My favorite parts of the game are the horses, clothing options, and realism of the game world. The PC UI takes some getting used to, and I could do without a lot of the forced grouping and combat, but otherwise this has become my favorite game. The horses are the best game horses I've ever seen and interacted with, and it's a pleasure to just ride slowly down the roads and trails and enjoy the wildlife and scenery. 

Tips: It's worth it to buy enough gold to get the Collector Role as soon as you can. This Role will easily give you the ingame cash you need to maintain your camp, pay for stables, and keep your horse well fed while you get going. Do the dailies and treasure maps (you get one every 5 levels) to make the gold to purchase your next Role. Loot all the NPC's you kill - they don't have much cash, but sometimes you will get a treasure map, things you can sell to a Fence, gun oil, and other useful items.

Beautifully crafted game, amazing visuals even on lower settings. The map is huge and it feels like there is always more to explore. I have seen a few reviews saying about hackers but so far I have only had one hacker experience and it wasn't really bad. Only problem is the fricking horse movement, I get it is probably meant to be realistic but my horse keeps doing goddamn circles when I am trying to run. 9.7/10

The game itself is beautiful, it sucks you in in an indescribable way. It's the most realistic game I've ever played. 

We played it with my boyfriend, it was a lot of fun and sometimes difficult but overall we were impressed by what this game had to offer. 

Unfortunately after a while you run out of activities and are left with nothing but repetition of missions. The whole community would be very happy if the developers hadn't dropped the game... there is a lot of potential in this game. 

In any case, I recommend it to everyone who loves the western style and atmosphere, because this game fully delivers it.

It's fun the first, oh, three hours? Conveniently I basically NEVER saw another player until past the 2 hour refund window- Did I say conveniently? I mean suspiciously. The instant that refund window was past, in the first and ONLY town I have access to, I get demolished by other players on sight, slamming me with horses to cause fatal damage, the moment I respawn another literally choking my character out in the middle of the street on sight, or my personal favorite: glitching my game to spawn an undressed male character model to follow me all throughout town that only went away when the player I suspect got bored. I guess there's no good way to report *literal* sexual harassment in this game, because only option I got was some BS way in which I could only put up a bounty for other players. For some reason I doubt the efficacy of that.

Which sucks. I want an old west style MMO to work, but the company that makes it OBVIOUSLY doesn't care- it's so bad I don't even want to get the offline games in order to not support this. Screw this game and it's predatory approach to everything, I'm pushing for my money back anyways.

If you are looking for a fun time without modding the game to force private lobbies, playing a cowboy/girl/entity, I cannot recommend this game. I loved playing this one my ps4, it was less annoying, occasionally a griefer but for the most part, I could play in peace. However, on pc its pathetic that 2 hours of gameplay was mostly being griefed, running from other players, and being surrounded by annoying script kiddies that break the game in so many ways it is frustating. Rockstar treats this game like a stepchild and isn't doing anything to fix any of these issues. The only fix for this is to intentionally lag the game via task manager for 10 seconds to get a private lobby that eventually gets ppl add to it or to get a mod that goes the notepad trick for you which gets something akin to a passcoded lobby. 

Outside of this issue, I love the game and the joy it brings me alone or with friends. Its honestly fun and its very beautiful graphically as well as the immersiveness to make your own stories in the game. If they would just add private lobbies or do something about the hackers and griefers, that would be a step in the right direction.

Fun while it lasted, but I've finally hung up my spurs after 4 years of play as it's been long abandoned by Rockstar so they can focus on development of GTA VI. That means no more new content, just old stuff recycled every few months. Really annoying bugs like the stable bug (that traps you in the stable and forces you to exit game via Rockstar social club) are still present even 2 years after the final update. It's biggest issue however is that cheaters using third party software have free reign now, so you can't even get any playtime without some idiot using auto-aim, infinite health, modded weapons etc. harassing players from afar using random explosions, teleports, or spawning all kinds of random enemies in free roam. Trying to report them will often auto-kick you, so it's pretty much a waste of time.
As RDO already comes bundled with RDR2, just buy that when it's on sale, as it's by far the best western game out there. RDO could have been great too, but it clearly didn't earn enough cash for Rockstar compared to GTAO, so they walked away from it and let it go to ruin.
P.S. my 50.6 hours is only through the Steam version. I've played hundreds of hours direct via the Rockstar launcher over the last 4 years.

I want to recommend this game so badly, because it is beautiful and well put together. 
But the fact that I have not been able to find a single server in WEEKS that is not full of people modding is getting frustrating. Areas where you are supposed to be safe are unsafe. I get headshotted at least once every session while buying things from the general store or the butcher. Modders chase you across the map with ease - if you fast travel they will just teleport to follow you. Pressing charges does nothing, reporting does nothing, the only thing you can do is keep server hopping until you (hopefully) find one without modders. The amount of times I have had to quit a great session out of frustration because someone randomly started attacking me and using cheats to throw me into the air, make my horse explode, make my items disappear, etc. is becoming too much. This game is not enjoyable if I have to fight for half an hour just to find a server that won't result in my immediate and incessant death. Boo.

Play this with caution, Modders have complete control in this game. The best equivalent i can make is, every lobby is a gta5 Loose RP server with power tripping Mods. At any point you can be targeted for nothing. 

Be me for a sec and imagine this scenario. Im taking my hides to sell them to a buyer. Out of nowhere a guy teleports next to my wagon, kills me, destroys the wagon. after i respawn he teleports over and over again to kill me. "fine, new lobby" *loads up new lobby, plays for 30 seconds, gets killed, realizes he followed me, because all you need in RDR2 online servers is someones in game tag to force themselves into you're lobby*. 

the "online" problem for this game is worse than the reviews make it out. Every lobby has at least one cheater, and they OWN THE GAME. For one let start out by pointing out its near impossible to get these guys banned, so long as they take even the most minor precautions. as i said, modders have total control of the game, and have many ways to keep you from reporting. my least favorite is when they crash your game before you can ever finish the report. They can also change names, resulting in others being reported who weren't cheating. plenty of those stories floating around. This game doesn't have dedid servers either, its peer to peer and for those in the crowd that means all the players are basically connecting to each other.... which means without a vpn, all they need is simply to be in you're lobby to get ips, and you're screwed if they so choose. some examples of the endless grief you'll see in this game is: endless tp killing, your horse will never live long enough to see you, you cant retaliate bc they cant be killed or harmed in any way, they can cage you in place, freeze your character, crash you're game, and i haven't even brought up ddos. Just don't bother with this game, unless you just really like being bullied GTA5 RP SissyMod style.

Now id like to address directly to the people who think this is just a salty bs review, and the mod greifing isn't as bad as i making it out to be. Go on YouTube and twitch, and look how healthy the content community is for Online. It ins't healthy, and anyone who does make content has addressed this issue, with much more frustration than I.

Ill wrap this up by pointing out to anyone whose hopeful Rockstar will fix this issue, this has been a problem since release, and they've watched it get worse while doing nothing. no hope for this heaping pile of online grief fest.

Edit: i almost forgot. most importantly, if you do buy the game, under no circumstances, for any reason, not even on opposite day, open a chest you don't know for a fact is supposed to be there. if you find a chest, you  better look on YouTube and Google until you can verify that's a real chest. Modders spawn in chests that give you gold.... and a permanent ban. Yeah that's right, Rockstar doesn't ban the cheater who spawned the chest, they ban the level 3 account who didn't know any better for opening it, because Rockstar doesn't care about cheaters greifing, they only care when someones getting premium currency for free instead of paying them.
