Great game if you love westerns.  A couple downs sides to it: Rockstar has abandoned the game(no new content) but it has a ton of variety and different things to do plus incredibly immersive.  The level of detail is amazing.  Another not so great aspect is that the game seems more designed for consoles and controllers then PCs and keyboards.  Their tips for doing stuff are not intuitive or easy to understand but once you get the hang of it it is loads of fun.  Also, the community is super toxic on the main online version lots of little punk hackers but there is a way to enter your own lobby(lots of instructions online).  So set it up for you and however many friends you want to play with to go through a separate lobby then you won't have to deal with hackers and punks.  Again, great game, wish Rockstar would keep developing it but it has a shload of playable hours as is!

Suffers from the same problems as GTA 5 Online. Hackers in every lobby whose favorite thing to do is teleport everyone in the session to them and blow everyone up. Slow loading times even with an NVMe SSD. Unskippable cutscenes in story missions.

An unfixed bug where your game will get stuck in a transition cutscene when you enter the Stable with your horse - you have to dismount and make it flee before entering the Stable.

Toggle Aim setting is broken where you will be kicked out of the right click menu a lot.

And a crazy expensive economy where every weapon, horse, and outfit costs hundreds of dollars while you earn only $15-$30 for every activity you complete.

Worth it if you liked the base game. Slow serious Wild West simulator. The community is also way healthier and friendlier than GTA V, you can tell it's a smaller but better older audience that enjoy the game at their own pace and let others do the same, barely seen any griefers or people just ruining other people's fun. It also helps that the map is huge I guess so no chance of hectic crazy off the wall unimmersive shenanigans of having airbikes, flying Deloreans, and drive-by shootings in every corner. You will have to grind like crazy or go through the cash shop for the cool missions aka roles like moonshining and bounty haunting, but at least you can pretend it's your own RPG with your mute self insert, rather than Arthur's Spaghetti Western movie, good as it was. I hope GTA VI online is more similar to this than V.

What is it like?
Cowboy simulator. Smooth animations, a detailed open world, stunning graphics, quality voice acting, and an incredible amount of polish. When I say this, I speak for both story (Red Dead Redemption 2) and online (Red Dead Online/this product). Both "modes" are actually extremely similar in what you can or cannot do. The main difference is that in online, you get to create and control your own protagonist who experience a different story. Who they become is up to you to decide. The entire map is available for exploration and most, if not all guns/horses/food/etc. available in story are also available in online.

What are the players like?
What players? After a few weeks of playing, I can count the number of people I have seen in free roam on my two hands. This can be both good and bad--if you like meeting new people in the game, you're better of using a third party site or platform to find friends. If you like to be immersed or are just weary of griefers, this is a godsend.
But for the people that I do see, what are they like?
GTA Online but most aren't blood-hungry psychopaths or literal Gods. A vast majority of the people you see will probably just ignore you. Tryhards/griefers and modders/cheaters are present, yes, but they are incredibly rare in my experience.

As for the ingame economy?
Cash is the standard currency--it's easy to get and earned from most things in the game. Gold is the "premium" currency of Red Dead Online; it can be used to bypass level restrictions, purchase roles, or be used in place of cash. It's a bit harder to come by compared to regular ol' cash, and is rewarded in smaller amounts. You will need a lot of it. Expect to farm/grind for currency often. Just keep in mind that there's no need to hurry. And don't get burned out. It's also important to note that the way rewards work in this game is a bit weird. In many instances, you get paid MORE cash/gold for taking LONGER to complete a mission or objective. So take your time and enjoy. Don't rush--you'll only sandbag your rewards anyways.

What should I be doing when I start?
When you first start out (after the tutorial missions), you will mostly be going to Horley and doing online's story missions for early cash and a bit of gold. Once you discover more lucrative sources to make bank, you can sort of "farm the way you want" with specialist roles. These "roles" or "jobs" let you earn cash by doing specific activities that are exclusive to said role. Like gunplay and lots of action? Save for a bounty hunter pass. Want to start a hunting business? Become a trader. Like alcohol? Sell moonshine! Are you intrigued by animals? Consider becoming a naturalist. Fond of exploration and/or treasure hunting? Collector. Note that getting into roles requires a steep gold investment and that only the bounty hunter role can earn gold from their activities.

Miscellaneous tips
- I recommend you buy the collector bag to become a collector as soon as possible. With the collector role, you can stock up on treasures found in the open world, then sell them in sets for a large sum of money. Each treasure you collect also gives you experience points to increase your rank. This is especially important because you get a treasure map every 5 ranks that provides you with a lot of gold and cash in addition to your other sources of income. I recommend looking for antique alcohol bottles and the Swords and Pentacles tarot card sets as these collectible sets are easily obtainable without any additional investment aside from the collector bag,
- Speaking of collector, hit shift+tab ingame to toggle the Steam overlay. Select "Web Browser" to open a new web browser tab within Steam overlay and search for "jeanropke map". This will lead you to a site with a virtual Red Dead Online map that updates in real time. With it, you can see the location of every collector item and mark them on your own map ingame. The map also has other important markets for fast travel points, Madam Nazar (collector vendor), legendary animal spawn locations, and some other useful things.
- Aim to upgrade your Carbine repeater to the Lancaster repeater. The Lancaster isn't too cheap but it has a high rate of fire as well as balanced range and accuracy, making it an all-around reliable weapon. Oh, and don't forget to clean your weapons every so often so that their stats are good. To do this, make sure you have gun oil in your inventory (purchased or looted), hover over a weapon and press the scroll wheel/middle click.
- Press L to pull up the player menu. You can do a lot from here but going to "Online options" at the very bottom allows you to change your playstyle between offensive (on by default) and defensive. Defensive mode is good for players who aren't looking to pvp, as it gives you damage resistance from players, disables auto aim lock on, immunity from executions and the lasso, and other buffs that promote pacifism.
- Don't forget to do your daily objectives (accessible from the player menu, L key). These are actually an incredible source of easy gold. Most challenges are pretty easy and there's always at least a few that don't require pvp or interaction with other players. You only need to complete one daily objective per day to start getting gold reward multipliers for them. The multiplier increases every 7 days, up to 28.
- The game seems to start with very low volume in Window's volume mixer. This is probably because the game's starting cutscene (the shotgun) is actually very loud on max volume. Be sure to check/change the game's volume in Windows mixer every time you boot it up or switch sessions.

A Wild West Playground with a Tarnished Soul

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

Red Dead Online is a game that has long lived in the shadow of its illustrious single-player counterpart. It's a sprawling, open-world Wild West playground that could have been a diamond in the rough, but it feels more like an abandoned frontier town left to decay.

Gameplay (★★★☆☆): When you saddle up and ride into the vast expanses of Red Dead Online, you can't help but be captivated by its potential. The core gameplay mechanics, inherited from Red Dead Redemption 2, are still there. The gunfights are gritty, the world is beautifully detailed, and the promise of forging your own cowboy legacy is enticing. It's this promise that keeps players coming back despite the game's issues.

Abandoned by Rockstar (★★☆☆☆): The most frustrating aspect of Red Dead Online is the feeling that Rockstar has left it to fend for itself in the lawless wilderness. Updates are sporadic, and it's clear that the studio's focus has shifted to other endeavors. This abandonment is felt through the lack of meaningful content updates and the absence of quality-of-life improvements that players have been clamoring for.

Neglected and Cheater's Paradise (★☆☆☆☆): It's not just the neglect; Red Dead Online is also plagued by rampant cheating. Hackers run amok, ruining the experience for everyone else. Rockstar's response to this issue has been lackluster at best, leaving legitimate players feeling powerless and frustrated.

In conclusion, Red Dead Online is a game with untapped potential, still riding the coattails of its single-player predecessor. It's a Wild West playground that desperately needs some love and attention from its creators. While the core gameplay can provide moments of enjoyment, the neglect from Rockstar and the unchecked cheaters tarnish what could have been a true gem of an online experience. Saddle up with caution, for this frontier is wild and unforgiving in more ways than one.

Game is very immersive, I have enjoyed playing online with the boys and all. But you simply cannot play peacefully for 2 hours without a low-life hacker in your session, spawning chests with gold or spawning tornadoes, etc. And for this... The game consistently crashes (or runs poorly)... Shoot, if you're interested into becoming a BAD*** moonshiner and pay IDK, 25+ gold bars, just to get it up and running. Be mindful that you need to spend $50 (or more) in game to start brewing, and once you get the boys together to run a mission. Be prepared to roll the dice with the server, your game might crash (lose all your moonshine and wait again) OR you score some dopamine once the game LOADS the mission. See? You don't roll the dice with the difficulty of the game, no, you roll the CHANCE of the game doing what its supposed to do. Don't get me wrong, I've enjoyed every second of this game, enjoyed hunting, gathering, fishing, bounty hunting, that grind was enjoyable and was different with every approach... It stops being enjoyable when the session doesn't connect/crashes (frequently), or have a boat land on your head whenever you are minding your own business... [ROCKSTAR] have given up on their own servers for Red Dead Online. Their newcomers aren't welcome here, and the hackers are creeping around in the servers like the little rats that they are LOL. Trust me, It's a joke and a waste of your meaningful time and money with your friends here. Buy the Original Red Dead Redemption 2 instead, and opt into another gaming company that respects your experience.

Worst tutorial ever.  Counter-Intuitive controls for just about everything except movement.  Step 3 in tutorial (after 'mount horse' which it explains how to do and then ride to town and find post office clerk which is also easy enough), is to enter the post office which results in shooting the door open and angering the locals, then you approach the clerk and the only option is to shoot him, it tells you to approach him then shows mouse with left button white and right button dark.  Tried both mouse button options.  Right button does nothing, even if held for many seconds.  Left button shoots the clerk.  What gives?  Horrible tutorial, in-game menus and 'help' and 'keybindings' do nothing to explain how to communicate with NPCs.  Internet is almost as bad.  Did I miss something?  I tried pressing space bar, pressing E (which is supposed to 'interact' with your target), hit just about every button.  FIgured out how to 'strafe' (or shoot while dodging to the side) in the process, but the most basic thing in any new-to-you-game is how to interact with a simple NPC.  This is insane.  Just wasted almost 2 hours trying to not shoot the clerk.

(online) I honestly don't understand rockstar. This game had unbelievably huge potential, and it was just so carelessly wasted. The game has a boring main story that you complete in like 2 hours of playtime, and all the roles are a joke. Dumb, useless, repetitive, boring garbage, for which you get paid a minuscule amount of money. And even then, you can't really spend that money on anything useful, all horses are the same, it doesn't matter if its a 1000$ horse or a 100$, it rides the same, the speed is the same. All guns feel the same, with barley any difference at all, it doesn't matter if you use a cattleman revolver or a navy revolver, most of the time you wont feel a difference. Card balancing is a joke, some are just straight up busted while others are just useless. There is absolutely no content what so ever, which makes the game feel old and boring after 3 hours of playtime. But the main problem, are the cheaters. Every 3rd person you see has a cheat menu, which makes the only thing going for this game, the player to player interaction, just straight up disgusting.
Honestly, it would be so much better if the online just didn't exist, cause now you just can't help but look at it, and think of what a great game this could have been.

dont really care for all these chinese hackers making the experience super crappy, add some damn anti cheat rockstar the chinese have ruined this game. I got blown up by an invisible force more times than i can recall only to listen to some mf singing in chinese.

The online is fantastic, that is when you manage to get a short break from all of the rampant cheating. 

Your every lobby has some amount of effect from a damned cheater and they are a damn plague and exist only to ruin every other persons game play.

It's almost hard to say whether the online is worse then GTA 5's current online state, and the circus going on there with the official servers (modding, issue) and how bad the problem appears to be there, but atleast Red Dead has a solid foundation and gameplay, unlike the careless additions they've made for GTA 5 with the futuristic stuff, flying vehicles etc as a short example. 

When playing, my experience in australia has been that somewhere close to half of every encounter is that of somebody using a cheat menu or that person having a friend with no other better thing to do then to come along and assist them with cheats cause their boy getting crapped on. 

I don't very well understand the mind of a cheater, them people are weak as piss. Yet somehow they manage to convince themselves they're better then a non cheater its bizarre. 

Rockstar isn't even bothered to poke a stick at this game when it comes to security, especially when the micro transactions for gold currency is essentially pointless when a cheat menu can spawn chests in game that reward users with the currency illegitimately. You know the publishers don't care at all when they aren't bothered to protect their bread and butter micro transactions. 

Card/perk system in my opinion needs some work, and the lack of the features which red dead 1's online had in comparison, mostly in regards to some of the animals you could mount and own.

There has been a lack of new content which the community has anxiously been waiting on for what seems like forever.

The issue with drowning, and ships sinking in the ocean without a clear border which states what is accessable and what is not.

Some glitches still existing with a large one being that your character becomes stuck when accessing the stable.

Still no Undead Nightmare..

A worrying concern is that of Rockstars recent purchase with the folks behind the custom launcher that allowed unofficial servers for both Gta 5's "Five M" and Red dead 2's "Red M".

A slightly increased player limit within the open world free roam would be more appropriate, given the scale of the map and todays tech now.

Review is set to positive, as the cheating issue lies mostly with the community, although the anti cheat has to be taken seriously, it is well overdue.

Not even on sale!  How to say how bad this game is...okay lets start with the tutorial.

Pretty much, this is how you shoot a gun and ride a horse.  After that it's good luck!  Nothing on how to fast travel, nothing about game mechanics or anything of the sort.  

Lets go with missions, at first I tried to sneak but the coin of visibility is pretty much 1 mile for those guys and would immediately spot me.  So I would sneak to the making a long circle, yeah got him!  Course there is another guy looking from 2 miles away that spots you and now you have to fight off 15 guys at a time.  I know what you're thinking, "that sounds exciting!" but no.  They all take cover which is fine but also they all know exactly where you are!  Jump into a ravine and sneak around to a barn?  Nope, as soon as you get there they already have you lined up and are firing.  So soon enough you find yourself dead.

All right fine, you're dead and it's time for a different approach right?  Wrong again!  Even though they killed you they are still on alert as to you being with their super amazing eye sight, they will start to shoot at you from a distance even through trees!  You can't see them do to the leaves but sure as day they see you just fine and when 10 of them are firing at you, they are bound to score a few hits.  So you're dead again.

Okay you think, screw missions, maybe I'll just wander around and take in the sights.  I have my flag up as protected so I don't have to worry about other players at least because it says right there when I raised it, "Raise flag for protection from other players".  Great I'm safe considering I'm a low level and would get beaten soundly instantly.  

But hold onto your hats folks because while wandering in the middle of town I get a player running up to me and fires a shot gun in my face...instant death.  Fine, I respawn, he is right there and does it again.  At this point I was done but because I kept spawning on top of him I couldn't even quit the stupid game because he would shoot me before I could!

In short, there's much better games out there worth playing.  But if you do want to play this, go ahead!  Some people just want to suffer.

In the left over state RDO has been left to, I cannot recommend. In the beginning, sure. Now, not so much. The only way to play "safely" without the constant intrusion of a hacker/mod menu player, is to go and get RDO Lobby Manager. However, with it, you can only play with your friends if you give them the code or by yourself. This IS the closest you can get to a "private" lobby.

Without it, the amount of times you'll run into one of the two previously mentioned, is high. Stupidly, high. Feel like going across the map? Hacker/Mod Menu. Feel like just trying to relax and be a cowboy/cowgirl, guess what? Hacker/Mod menu player. It doesn't stop regardless of where you go or what you try to do. Nothing is "safe". Oh and don't try reporting ANY of them through the game's player menu. If you do, your game will be closed just for trying to report them. That is how bad the hacking is right now, they are able to literally kick you out of the game for trying to do the right thing. R* sucks and DON'T buy or pre-order the next GTA that comes out, if they can't improve RDO but can constantly improve GTA Online, what's that tell you?

I am giving it thumbs up because it's one of the best & most unique online experiences out there, a perfect integration of multiplayer into an open world environment. This is what we all wish MMOs actually were, and in my opinion what they should be (not massive, but a fluid "lobby" system like what RDO is). Few games have nailed this sort of thing so well. RDR1's multiplayer was amazing as well, and this is nothing but an upgrade upon that

That being said, I highly recommend you don;t purchase this, and instead get the full RDR2. RDO, or BCO (Bing Chilling Online) is completely filled with hackers on PC, and it ruins the experience. It's been an ongoing issue for years and they have never done anything significant to deal with it, so at this point it's a lost cause now that BCO is officially abandoned by Rockstar. If you are able to go more than an hour without a Bing Chilling user spawning cages around you or spamming explosives at your location, you are lucky - that's not an exaggeration at all. BCO has lots of jobs you can do which have a high risk factor (which is part of the fun) - but you are literally 10x more likely to get griefed irrecoverably by hackers in the middle of a mission than you are to get attacked by an honest player

I originally purchased this because I had already done RDR2 on the PS4 and thought I would only want to play online. Now I see my mistake. As far as I know there's no discount for Bing Chilling Online owners to purchase the singleplayer version

Rockstar is as good at immersive open worlds and cinematic storytelling, as they are bad at core gameplay and meta mechanics.  

This online-only mode neglects the former, and doubles down on the latter.

I used to love playing RDO; the community was fun and friendly, the ambience and world details were great, and my friends and I got hundreds of hours of entertainment out of being cowpokes. Unfortunately, Rockstar has given up on the game, and I can no longer recommend that anyone spend time or money on it. They've cited a small player base for their reason to discontinue updates, but what's anyone's incentive to continue playing an online game if we go a year or more without any new content? The server connectivity issues have gotten to the point where playing with friends is borderline impossible. I'm currently writing this because our group has been trying (and failing) for 40 minutes to stay in the same Call to Arms session with each other. I don't know, it's just sad. I appreciate the memories, but it's time to move on.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece, a breathtaking opus that transcends the boundaries of video games and stands as a testament to the unparalleled magic of interactive storytelling. From the very moment you step foot into its meticulously crafted world, you are transported to a realm of unmatched beauty and complexity, where every cobblestone and blade of grass tells a tale.

The game's narrative prowess is a tour de force, a symphony of emotions that grips your heart and refuses to let go. Arthur Morgan's journey is one of profound self-discovery, a redemption arc that rivals the greatest tales of literature and cinema. The characters that populate this vast canvas are not mere digital constructs; they are living, breathing souls with dreams, flaws, and histories that will leave an indelible mark on your psyche.

The open world itself is a triumph of design and detail. From the bustling streets of Saint Denis to the serene vistas of the Grizzlies, every locale feels alive, each corner teeming with secrets waiting to be unearthed. The sheer scope of activities and interactions is staggering – whether you're engaging in intense shootouts, embarking on epic hunts, or simply sitting by a campfire strumming your guitar, the world reacts to your every move with a sense of authenticity rarely achieved in gaming.

Graphically, Red Dead Redemption 2 sets an unsurpassed standard. The play of light and shadow, the intricate textures, and the meticulous attention to environmental nuances elevate this game to an artistic marvel. It's not just about graphical fidelity; it's about the synergy between visual craftsmanship and narrative cohesion, making every frame a work of art that propels the story forward.

But it's not just the grandeur that makes this game unforgettable; it's the small moments, the quiet interactions, and the subtleties that weave together to form a rich tapestry of experiences. The conversations around the campfire, the camaraderie shared with your horse, and the sense of wonder as you stumble upon hidden gems in the wilderness – these are the elements that breathe life into the world and make it feel like a living entity.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is more than a game; it's an emotional odyssey that resonates long after the credits roll. It's a reflection on the complexities of human nature, a meditation on morality and consequence, and a love letter to a bygone era. It's a rare gem that seamlessly blends technology and art to create an experience that defies classification.

In the end, Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just a game you play; it's a world you inhabit, a story you become a part of, and an adventure that etches itself into your soul. It's a triumph of imagination, a testament to the power of interactive media, and a reminder that gaming can be a form of high art. If there's one game you owe it to yourself to experience, it's this magnum opus – a true pinnacle of the medium that will stand the test of time.

Red Dead Online, the multiplayer component of the critically acclaimed Red Dead Redemption 2, is an absolute blast. From the stunning visuals and breathtaking landscapes to the authentic Western atmosphere, this game will immerse you in a world unlike any other.

One of the best aspects of Red Dead Online is the freedom it provides. You can choose to embark on story missions, hunt wild game, explore the vast open world, go bounty hunting, or simply hang out with friends in your camp. The possibilities are endless and it’s all up to you.

The multiplayer component adds an exciting layer to the gameplay. Whether you’re playing cooperatively with friends or competing against other players, there’s always something to do.

The customization options in this game are impressive, allowing players to create their own unique character and build a reputation within the game. And with the ability to purchase weapons, clothing, there’s a real sense of progression as you become more powerful and influential within the game world.

Of course, the game isn’t perfect. The matchmaking can sometimes be a little slow, the many hackers, and the recurring bugs can be frustrating. However, these issues are relatively minor compared to the overall experience Red Dead Online provides.

In conclusion, if you’re a fan of the Western genre or simply love a good multiplayer game. It’s immersive, entertaining, and just plain fun.

[h1] Red Dead Online Review [/h1]

Red Dead Online, while it definitely falls short in comparison to its story counterpart, is a great, cheap way to play RDR2 with your friends. Sadly, even though I've been playing this for a while I'm unsure if I can recommend it.

You can explore, taking on missions and heists with friends, battling lawmen, gangs and dangerous animals to forge your own path on the American Frontier. You can ride solo or form a posse (party) with your friends and take in all that the world of RDR2 has to offer, from farms and busy towns to large mountains and snowy landscapes. You can also become a bounty hunter, fish, hunt, run your own Moonshine distillery, and more.

Now lets get to the bad bit, the microtransactions. Most of the fun parts of RDO, like being a bounty hunter, are often put behind paywalls with RDO's premium currency called gold bars. And there are challenges that only give you 0.10 of a bar, so you can see how annoying grinding for gold is to get that business or whatever you want. And I have heard it has gotten worse since the launch of this standalone version, with Rockstar nerfing the daily missions to give less gold.

Red Dead Online is a great way to experience almost all that RDR2 has to offer, but the microtransactions and the grind, while not as bad as GTAO, still feels bad and the amount of paywalls you can hit, especially when starting a business, makes the game feel boring and slow. I would suggest you get the story mode, that is where the good game is. In conclusion, RDO is a great introduction to RDR2 but sadly it feels like only the foundation is there, and there is just no actual meat to the game - at least - none that doesn't require hours of grinding or malicious microtransactions. Due to these things, as it stands I just can't recommend this until Rockstar fix the problems that have been plaguing this version of the game for a while.

EDIT: Yeaaaah, theres literally no reason to buy this, Rockstar abandoned it. Don't waste your money.

Epic Adventure: "Red Dead Redemption 2 swept me off my boots and straight into the heart of the Old West. From epic gunfights to heartwarming moments at the camp, every step of Arthur Morgan's journey left me feeling like a true frontier legend. The vast landscapes and immersive world made me forget I was just a rootin'-tootin' gamer, and for a while, I was a gunslingin' outlaw."Stunning Realism: "I couldn't believe my eyes playin' Red Dead Redemption 2 – the graphics were so sharp, I could see the tumbleweeds rollin' in the wind! Every detail, from the creak of the leather saddle to the glint of sunlight off a tin can, had me feelin' like I was livin' in the Wild West myself."Emotional Rollercoaster: "Red Dead Redemption 2 had me laughin', cryin', and holdin' my breath like a rodeo rider. The relationships between the characters were so deep that by the end, I felt like they were kinfolk. The story's twists and turns had me gripped tighter than a rattlesnake's coil."Open-World Marvel: "Talk about freedom! Red Dead Redemption 2's open world had me explorin' like a pioneer. Whether I was chasin' down bounties or takin' a leisurely ride through the countryside, there was always somethin' excitin' to do. It's like they packed a whole frontier into my console."Horse Whisperer's Dream: "I never thought I'd get so attached to a bunch of pixels, but Red Dead Redemption 2's horses stole my heart. The bond I formed with my trusty steed was somethin' else – groomin', feedin', and ridin' together made me feel like a true cowboy with a loyal companion."Spaghetti Western Bliss: "Red Dead Redemption 2 delivered that classic spaghetti western feel I've been cravin'. The showdowns, the duels, and the showdowns turned this game into a cinematic masterpiece. It's like Clint Eastwood handed me the reins and said, 'You're the new sheriff in town, partner.'

After nearly spending 300 hours on this game, I think I'm allowed to give it a review.
This game is potentially the best game that exists, at least it's definitely the best wild-west game.
The realism must be unmatched, the way the animals react, the human ai, the hunting - even from shooting someone in one of their major artilleries and watching them bleed out.
One of the most realistic features is the police - in story mode, if you had a mask up or no one saw you commit a crime, then you get wanted - you can convince the police it wasn't you!
The story, while sad, is one of the best i've ever seen, maybe seconding to the last of us. 
It's brilliant, and it is worth every penny. The online and story modes will definitely give you an experience that you'll play over atleast twice.
I might be a fanboy, but I've played through the game 3 times and am currently on my fourth.
Very worth it, the game can't get old.

DISCLAIMER: This review is about the whole game including story mode and online, because I had bought RDO as a standalone game in late 2020 for 5$, then upgraded to Story Mode making it possible for me to play both, but Steam will keep showing that I own only RDO, a very smart move from Rockstar. I'll divide the review into 2 parts, I'll keep the old RDO review as it is because I didn't change my mind.

RDR2:
The game has an awesome and emotional story, the realism is just wow, a big map to explore and tons of activities to do like exploring, carriage stealing, bounty hunting etc... I feel lucky being alive at the time of RDR2 release.


RDO: (from September 2022)
No doubt that Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of the best games of all time, I appreciate and respect all the time, effort and dedication Rockstar gave this game, it pushed me into the western genre of movies such as the iconic The Good, The Bad And The Ugly (1966), as well as many more. When Red Dead Online became a stand-alone title in December 2020 I grabbed it for 5 bucks, excited to try the online side of my favorite game of all time with my friends, it all went good at first but once you complete everything it becomes boring as hell, especially if you have no one to play with. I expected it to be as rich in content as GTA Online, but for some reason Rockstar abandoned the game, no update as of September 2022 (the last update was in July 2021), many bugs that are unfixed, some argue that all Rockstar studios are busy with GTA VI, others argue that the game no longer brings profit to Take-Two Interactive (The parent company of Rockstar Games) and thus had to suddenly cut support.
I like RDO a lot, but I'm a bit sorry and disappointed to not recommend it, the truth must be told. It has an enormous potential though.

Red Dead Online: A Disastrous Playground for Modders and Hackers

Red Dead Online, the highly anticipated multiplayer component of the critically acclaimed Red Dead Redemption 2, has become a nightmare due to the overwhelming presence of modders and hackers, further exacerbating the game's existing issues and leaving players with a frustrating and unplayable experience.

One of the most pervasive problems plaguing Red Dead Online is the rampant presence of modders. These malicious individuals exploit vulnerabilities in the game's code to gain unfair advantages, disrupt gameplay, and ruin the experience for legitimate players. From teleporting across the map to spawning infinite resources or invulnerable characters, modders create an imbalanced and chaotic environment that undermines any semblance of fair play.

The sheer number of modders in Red Dead Online is astonishing. Almost every session is infested with these individuals, making it nearly impossible to enjoy the game as intended. Their disruptive behavior ranges from spawning absurd objects and creatures, such as flying horses or oversized characters, to manipulating the economy and causing widespread inflation. These actions completely destroy the immersion and ruin any sense of accomplishment or progress that players strive for.

The impact of modders extends beyond mere disruptions and glitches. They also pose a significant security risk to players. By injecting malicious software and malware into the game, modders can compromise the personal information and privacy of unsuspecting players. This flagrant disregard for player safety is a glaring failure on the part of Rockstar Games to provide a secure and protected online environment.

Regrettably, Rockstar Games' response to the modding epidemic has been inadequate. Despite numerous reports and complaints from the player base, the company has shown a lack of urgency in addressing the issue. Infrequent updates and a sluggish approach to banning and penalizing modders have allowed the problem to persist, frustrating players who long for a fair and enjoyable online experience.

The presence of modders not only disrupts the gameplay but also exacerbates the already existing technical issues in Red Dead Online. Modding can often lead to crashes, freezes, and connectivity problems, further hindering players' ability to enjoy the game. It's disheartening to witness the deterioration of a potentially engaging online experience due to the unchecked activities of a small but highly disruptive group.

In conclusion, Red Dead Online's failure to address the overwhelming presence of modders and hackers has turned what should have been a captivating multiplayer experience into a nightmare. The pervasive disruption, unfair advantages, and security risks posed by these individuals diminish the enjoyment and undermine the integrity of the game. Rockstar Games must take immediate action to combat modders, implement effective anti-cheat measures, and restore a sense of fairness and security to Red Dead Online. Otherwise, the game will continue to serve as a breeding ground for chaos and frustration, driving away players seeking an authentic and enjoyable online Wild West adventure.

Cheating is rampant. This basically breaks the online component of the game. Progression is completely non-intuitive. I like the core game and it's beautiful in terms of the assets, but the multiplayer aspect of the game is just nonfunctioning and the game has no support from the devs.

You can have good, fun moments when you're not being griefed by cheat nerds. Reporting does nothing and seems to notify the cheat nerds, they seem aware of when you report them.

:::UPDATE:::
Many of the issues with cheating and security can be resolved by playing private servers. There are guides and discords set up for small communities to play together. This resolves like 66% of my issues with the game. Do I play? Yes. Do I enjoy the game? Yes. Do I recommend you purchase? Considering I see this game as fundamentally broken, no. I do not feel like it's a waste of time though, you can have fun, once you figure out how to fix the game yourself.

I bought this game when it was on sale for 9.99. I haven't had very many issues with modders as i set my online settings to defensive and it seems to keep hostilities to a minimum with other players. it's a lot of fun, and well worth the money spent. the graphics are pretty amazing even running this game completely in wine using a rtx 4070ti, nvidia 535 drivers on popos using xandmod mainline kernel, great performance, i honestly can't tell the difference between windows 11 and linux. but besides that, this game is fun to play with friends. the landscape is rural and wide open lands to explore. the towns are vibrant and very detailed, just like in any old western movies. there are many robberies to commit, scalps to collect, Capitale to be made. This game will keep you intrigued. this is coming from a very recently ex-wow player... the world is so much more interesting and alive, and the community so far has been a treasure. there is an interesting crafting system as well, and the old time feeling of the catalog (kinda like JC Whitley) to purchase all of your weapons, liquor, and provisions... this game is aces better than most online games. really fun if you form a posse with friends and go looking for bounties. and there is no monthly subs... all worth it...

Rating: ★★★☆☆

[b]Pros:[/b]

[b]Stunning Visuals and Immersive World:[/b] The game's visuals and meticulously crafted open world create an immersive Wild West experience.

[b]Diverse Activities and Missions:[/b] Red Dead Online offers a wide range of activities and missions, ensuring there's always something to do.

[b]Roleplaying Opportunities:[/b] Specialized roles like Bounty Hunter, Trader, and Collector allow players to customize their experience and engage in unique activities.

[b]Co-op Possibilities:[/b] Playing with friends or joining a posse enhances the multiplayer experience through teamwork and camaraderie.

[b]Cons:[/b]

[b]Grind and Slow Progression:[/b] The game can feel excessively grindy, requiring repetitive tasks and significant time investment for meaningful progress.

[b]Limited Content Updates:[/b] New content and updates have been relatively slow, leaving some players craving more variety and freshness in the game.

The game keeps having loading issues and leaves you stuck on infinite loading screens.  content would be more enjoyable if they fixed the errors with their network and server.  Finish a mission but can't do anything but Alt+F4 the game as no menu can be accessed until the server decides to wake up, play a cinematic after completing the mission, then let you go. Until then you are held hostage to the nothing.

Below is my earlier rating since the complaints still stand, but it's overall still a game I want to play.

Game crashes with ffffff error for no reason. Randomly will get stuck in cilnematic view where I can't access or see anything of my inventory unless I force Alt+F4 the game the re-launch it. Sometimes when I go to climb onto the horse, the horse will disappear and I have to call for it to come back from wherever it glitched to and wait for it to run to me from the edge of my radar.  Just enough bugs to make the enjoyable part of the game just barely enjoyable, if not ruined.

Edit:  This error likes to happen immediately after completing missions before the free roam world can load, making their completion invalid and forcing me to restart the whole mission again, hoping it completes and doesn't FFFFFFF itself into the memory hole.

Edit:  I completely forgot to mention the lack of oversight that prevents players from modding/manipulating/hacking/exploiting whatever they are utilizing and harassing other players online. Nothing like being in the middle of a bounty mission with your posse and about to bind the person you're about to pick up and turn in for a bounty when suddenly in the middle of a dry cactus field, my character  spontaneously combusted and exploded, killing not only me, but also the target for the bounty and the other posse member helping with the capture.

I love Red Dead Online. I love being a cowboy, and playing the role content, my favorites being Naturalist and Collector. The map is huge and really, REALLY pretty. Even tho you can't stable them like in the base game, you can still tame wild horses and use them till you're bored. Customizing weapons is great, making outfits is fun if you're into glams and yes, they offer bright pink options for the extra flamboyant types. I have a whole RP character for this game that I've built on over time. I could sit on this game for hours just to hunt, just to relax after a long day.

But there are CONS. You can't transfer over user data from other consoles, you can't make multiple characters so you're limited to only the one (which sucks cuz I started on XBOX and I miss my OG boi. I took the opportunity to use my PC character slot to make his cannon little sister). The HACKERS are just getting out of hand. I can't log in and play at all at this point without being hacked, instantly becoming an outlaw with max bounty on my head, being caged in with a bear, or dying to explosions. I really wish we could make private servers so we can play alone or with a couple friends instead of strangers, or Rockstar would actually handle the hacking situation instead of letting it spiral out of control.

If you're one of the many unlucky souls to be plagued with the now-infamous ERROR #FFFFFFFF glitch, this game will be all but completely useless to you. There are a million and a half "fixes" for it online, yet apparently depending on your karmic debt you'll either get one to work for you or you'll spend the rest of your time in RDO starting a mission just to have the game crash on you. Or spend a ton of capitale on a job and have the game tank right when its loading, robbing you of your hard-earned mafia money. Or how about battling a legendary animal for what seems like forever, only to have the game crash right when you're pulling up to Gus? It's these examples and 1 million more that you'll find yourself dealing with by playing RDO on PC. I dumped PSN/PS4 just so I could play this game as it was intended on PC... and honestly, for all of PSN and R*'s shenanigans, this game is EVEN WORSE on PC (aside from the amazing graphics.) So for $20, sure- give the dice a roll. You'll either be swimming in enough lush graphics to make your head spin, or you'll be cursing every single person who ever had a hand in developing, neglecting and ultimately DESTROYING one of the best-ever online games I've played. Good fucking job, R*... I hope the GTA6 launch is a massive technical failure for you on all fronts.

Other than the lack of content for the multiplayer, this game is pretty much a piece of art. The story and environment are truly beautiful. I've never been able to sit at a game for a super long time, until I played this game. I've done nothing except the story, hunting, and di cking around with my friends.(Played it on the console first, and then switched to PC) Only problems I have with the game is that there are no more content updates, and that sometimes you will have a GTA 5 situation and run into a modder. Nothing that makes the game unplayable though. Overall a great game and I would really recommend sitting back, relaxing, and enjoying.

Red Dead Online is the multiplayer component of Red Dead Redemption 2, developed by Rockstar Games. In this review, I'll provide an overview of Red Dead Online and highlight its key features and aspects.

Red Dead Online transports players to the expansive open-world of the American frontier, offering a vast and immersive multiplayer experience. Set in the same time period as Red Dead Redemption 2, the game allows players to create their own unique character and embark on various activities within the shared online world.

One of the standout features of Red Dead Online is its rich and detailed open world. The game beautifully recreates the landscapes and environments of the Wild West, from sprawling deserts to dense forests and vibrant towns. The world feels alive, with dynamic weather, day-night cycles, and a variety of wildlife to encounter.

Red Dead Online offers a wide range of activities and missions for players to engage in. You can team up with friends or other players to tackle story-based missions, go on hunting expeditions, participate in competitive multiplayer modes, or even form a posse and engage in player-versus-player showdowns. The game also introduces various roles, such as bounty hunter, trader, and collector, which provide unique gameplay opportunities and progression paths.

The game's progression system allows you to earn experience, unlock new abilities, and acquire better equipment as you advance. Red Dead Online also features a robust economy, where you can earn money through various activities and spend it on weapons, clothing, and camp upgrades.

Red Dead Online encourages player interaction and cooperation through its dynamic world. You can form or join posses, take part in events and challenges, or simply explore the world alongside other players. The game's online community brings a social element to the experience, creating opportunities for both friendly cooperation and intense rivalries.

While Red Dead Online offers a compelling multiplayer experience, some players have raised concerns about the game's economy and the balance of in-game currency. Additionally, occasional technical issues and the occasional need for grinding to progress have been reported. However, Rockstar Games has been actively updating and improving the game over time, addressing many of these concerns.

In conclusion, Red Dead Online delivers an immersive multiplayer experience set in the vast and detailed world of the Wild West. With its diverse activities, engaging missions, and dynamic online community, it offers a compelling and enjoyable multiplayer experience for fans of the Red Dead Redemption series and those looking for a unique online adventure.

The only reason that I got this game is so that I could live out my quiet lonely wild west dream as a woman. That's it. All I do is hunt and sell whatever I've killed, maybe occasionally a rescue mission if I stumble on one. I use a lobby manager that makes sure I load into one with no players. I have absolutely no desire to play this for any social experience or to get into the story or anything remotely like that, this is just therapy for me. I miss the western landscape after having moved away from it and I miss it dearly. This is the closest I can get to recapturing that, and it serves its purpose well.

This is probably not the review to read if you want a genuine opinion on this thing as an MMO because I have no desire to play it as one. *BUT*, if you just want a neat little hunting game on horseback, this is for you, I think. Even if Rockstar never updates it again, I really hope that I'll be able to keep playing it for many years to come.

From what I've heard, the main game, that costs significantly more than online mode, works fine, but if you don't want to pay the high price, don't play at all. Here's why:

Online mode has so many bugs and hackers that it's unplayable. There was a glitch that causes the player to get stuck in the stables to the point that the only way out was to exit the entire game. This bad of a glitch took over two months to fix. 

Now there's glitches with horse AI, which is detrimental to the game, where the horse will randomly run into a tree, not auto-jump, or get spooked and buck you off repeatedly even if the horse seems calm. If you cannot use your horse in this game, it is barely playable as your character is very slow in comparison. At this point, the horse is unusable, and who knows when this glitch will get fixed, if ever.  

Not only that, but the game kicks the player out with a frozen screen and error message, or the tab just closes entirely with no warning. It doesn't matter what is being done in the game, there seems to be no pattern to it, but maybe there is. If there is, it's extremely specific, but occurs often. 

And lastly, the amount of hackers in this game are terrible. There's most likely one in every server. It's considered a miracle if there ISN'T one in a server. These people often blow up players and continue to do so every time one respawns. This is another situation in which the player must leave the game or switch servers. Switching servers may not seem like a huge deal, but the time it takes to load the game up is significant. Hackers will also spawn exotic animals that cannot be sold, farm money by spawning wagon missions and teleporting the wagon to the end point, spawning items in players hands so the player cannot use their gun or get on their horse, or an exploiter may make themselves immune to any damage while they go on a rampage on NPC's and players. Also, it is very common to come across a random animal that is shooting fire out of it's side, head, rear-end, feet, etc. Fire also spawns on stationary objects such as buildings, wagons, rocks, and plants. If you expect to get this game and NOT see hacker in your first play session, you would be the luckiest person on earth not to see one. 

The game itself is in my top five favorite games. I LOVE this game, yet it is simply unplayable. The game is so good that I wish I never knew it existed because of the terrible state it's in. I know what I'm missing out on due to the game getting zero love from it's developers. So unless you want to get attached to this game and slowly get increasingly more depressed about it's unplayability, DO NOT BUY THIS.

I'm trying to play this game in coop in 2023. Almost five years after its release, and its one of the buggiest and most unstable games i've ever played.

On my first day we've seen:

Random crashes with Unknown error FFFFFFFF.
Hackers on PC! Invincibility, aimbots, teleportation, explosions etc.
NPCs shooting fire from their heads.
Horses running around with burning hooves.
My own horse dying from said burning hooves.
Invisible horses.
Invisible friends.
Massive desync.
Friends not being correctly brought into missions (even when in the same posse).
Missions not correctly starting and simply resulting in all map icons to disappearring.
Unnecessary and long loading screens.
Missions where you have to pickup money bags yet only some of them are actually retrievable.
Randomly exploding whilst AFK. Then stuck in a never end 'killed yourself by explosion' loop till you ALT F4.
Random crashing resulting in game stored on your horse being lost.
Etc etc.

The controls, camera, and UI are also very cumbersome and clearly designed with consoles in mind. Oh, then there's the money/gold grind.

I honestly expected FARRRRRR better from R*!


Not sure why it's so hard for then simply to add PROPER coop to their games from the get go. Even Indie games can do it these days...

Okay, let me be clear. This is not a good game. However, if you like to place yourself, mentally, into your character this game may be for you.

This game has a lot of strange bugs and mechanics that may make it difficult to enjoy at times, there are also plenty of mod-ers and hackers that try and ruin your fun. My suggestion here is to learn the bugs, they are easily avoidable, learn the mechanics like bullet lead its unlike any other shooter, and in the case of hackers and modders, hop to a different session do not engage that's what they want.

For me I really like this game. I have a scary 'Jack the Ripper' looking character and I am not an easy fight. The old west style fits this character and allows me to create interesting narratives as I play the monotonous game that this is. What I am getting at is there is not much here, but that allows for you to fill in the gaps and create your own story. 

So yeah, I have to say its fun especially with some buddies but this game has a lot of grinding at the START of your Red Dead Online career and some bugs and some poor sport players. All avoidable but you have to look for the ways in which to avoid these crummy things.

Every 4 out of 5 online sessions has a grief hacker.  Is totally unplayable in free roam.   Rockstar just up and abandoned this game.  No updates or content.  No support.  Lack of caring by rockstar for quality of content and sustainability.

EDIT as of 07/13/21 The Release of the "Blood Money" Update:'

Blood Money' is essentially a creatively void, low-effort 'Stranger Mission' expansion. Without exaggeration, the boredom sets in less than two minutes into the new content and it's never relieved at any point.

Capitale, the fourth currency to be introduced in RDO, must be slowly and tediously earned by grinding a series of vapid, uninspired 'Stranger Missions.' Capitale is then exchanged for the opportunity to buy a 'Blood Money Opportunity,' however, the earning rate here has been throttled in order to encourage players to buy gold to advance. These 'Blood Money Opportunities' are not heists; these are not multi-stage robberies. They are essentially glorified 'Story Missions' with similarly structured garbage payouts.

Reward vs. time-spent here is an abomination. Economically this content is worthless.

New outfits, including Arthur Morgan's beloved Haraway outfit, were introduced at a premium of 52 gold bars, not including the 25 gold bars that must be spent in order to unlock the first of four new Quick Draw Pass iterations.'Weapon Ammo Pouch Pamphlets' introduced in the previous Outlaw Pass were made available for an absurd $2000 in-game. This pamphlet only applies to normal ammo however, and doesn't expand special ammo capacity.

Curiously, the developers failed to add any new horses, guns, clothing, or cosmetics outside of what little was offered in the Quick Draw Pass. Content creators have amassed hundreds of thousands in cash and gold over the past year and it will be at least another nine months before there is anything to spend it on.

Finally, 'Blood Money' re-introduced a slew of different game-breaking bugs and hard crashes which render RDO nearly unplayable.

The speed of Rockstar's decline over the past year has been staggering, having gone from being the darlings of the games industry to caving with rat-like enthusiasm to the mirco-transaction currency loop. This community had been hanging on by a thread before this latest spectacular failure. RDO is a shambles and should be allowed to die.

Review:

While certainly a pretty game, Red Dead Online unfortunately lets itself down by being desperately starved for content while Rockstar are satisfied miserably whoring gold off what little the game has to offer. The most puzzling thing about RDO is that where there was nearly limitless potential upon the games release, we now find an indifferent, middling, cowboy shooter that has worn out the players goodwill.

RDO suffers from a stingy economy and tedious gameplay. Mission rewards are based off of time spent rather than efficiency or kills, inevitably leading to players/ streamers being mired in downtime simply in order to be properly compensated for their efforts.

Animations are protracted and overlong, even when involving straightforward actions like skinning an animal, (this required a cut-scene?) Rockstar bully the player into paying for 'quality of life' changes such as fast-travel and weapon storage.

New updates require premium currency (gold) to buy-in, while offering limited re-playability and paltry content offerings. Recent changes have included the introduction of character roles (bounty hunter, etc.) and telegram missions. When properly structured these missions can be delightful and rewarding to play, however, many tasks hardly vary from the escort or fetch quest mission types from GTA Online.

Perhaps most regrettably, rather than give the game a clean death as the result of a diminishing player population, RDO has become mainly populated by role playing posses, whose factions exist outside of normal game servers. These people can hardly be blamed through; with the silence coming from Rockstar North the role players may be the only thing keeping this game solvent.

Much like GTA Online before its reinvention with the addition of the 'Doomsday,' 'Diamond Casino,' and 'Cayo Perico Heists,' RDO will not be rescued without the introduction of the 'big update.' Until such a time that this update arrives, RDO cannot be endorsed, and might well be considered the great 'missed opportunity' of the modern industry era.

[h1]It is sometimes a last resort short of a class action lawsuit that gets real muddy after the fact. But I believe if we REALLY want Rockstar Games to bring back support for this game, we need to get it into the media for games like IGN, Gamology, GameByte etc...[/h1] 

To do that, a review bomb of this game explaining our unpleasant experiences with the company itself and the game post-launch and then dropped support will be enough to get Rockstars attention.

[h1]Why do I think this will work?[/h1]

I think this will work, to prevent someone with a lot of time and a lot of money from getting further aggravated by the game company. There has been a rumor floating around on Facebook between groups that someone is preparing a lawsuit against Rockstar Games for unethical business and not delivering a product that they promised and over-billing of the customer. In the alleged Rumor, they have said that GTA is also applicable in this alleged lawsuit production, not just Red Dead.

But as to why I think my theory to get their attention will work is because it worked with Activision/Infinity Ward with Call of Duty, Microsoft/343 with Halo and it worked with Fatshark with Warhammer 40k Darktide among a few other games like Ground Branch and Ready or Not.

As the player and consumer, we hold the power of the purse. Laying down and accepting defeat is exactly what Rockstar wants so they can continue to get away with exploiting their playerbase and fans for money for a product they don't intend to continue to support without being forced into action. 

I've been a monetary investor in Rockstar for 10 years now, I have pulled my own support from their investment side as the first step for myself. I want to go farther so I am reaching out to the community in hopes to gain support.

Well, howdy there, folks! Today, I reckon I'm fixin' to give y'all a review of Red Dead Redemption 2 Online. Now, let me tell ya, this here game is somethin' special. It's like ridin' a wild stallion through the open prairie, filled with all sorts of adventures and misadventures.

The first thing that struck me 'bout Red Dead Redemption 2 Online is the sheer beauty of them landscapes. From the majestic mountains to the dusty plains, the attention to detail is just jaw-droppin'. It's like steppin' right into a real-life wild west.

Now, the gameplay itself is as smooth as a buttered biscuit. Whether you're wranglin' cattle, takin' on outlaws, or huntin' down varmints, the controls feel natural and responsive. And the variety of activities you can partake in is downright impressive. You can join up with yer buddies and form a posse, or you can go it alone and make a name for yourself in them lawless lands.

One thing that sets Red Dead Redemption 2 Online apart is the way it makes ya feel like a part of the world. You can choose to be an honorable gunslinger helpin' folks in need, or you can become a notorious outlaw robbin' banks and causin' mayhem. The choices you make have real consequences, and it adds a layer of depth to the whole experience.

Now, I gotta admit, there are a few hiccups here and there. Sometimes the servers can be a tad unreliable, and you might run into the occasional bug. But Rockstar Games has been mighty diligent in fixin' them issues, and they keep addin' new content to keep things fresh.

All in all, Red Dead Redemption 2 Online is a hoot and a holler of a game. It captures the spirit of the wild west like no other, and it offers a heapin' helpin' of fun for cowboys and cowgirls alike. So grab yer trusty steed and saddle up, 'cause there's adventures awaitin' in them there digital frontiers!

Red Dead Online: A Wild West Wonderland for Modders and Mayhem!

Saddle up, cowpokes, because Red Dead Online is an adventure like no other! Get ready to traverse the untamed frontiers of the Wild West, where modders and hackers roam freely, turning the game into a twisted yet strangely captivating playground.

Let's start with the modders, those creative individuals who seem to have found their calling in breaking the game's delicate balance. From transforming horses into UFOs to turning saloons into impromptu discotheques, their imaginative shenanigans never cease to amaze (and frustrate) unsuspecting players. Just when you think you're about to enjoy a peaceful ride through the countryside, along comes a modder, turning your trusty steed into a rainbow-colored monstrosity. 

But wait, there's more! Alongside the modders, you'll find a motley crew of hackers who possess an uncanny ability to bend the rules of the virtual world. While their actions may occasionally disrupt the gameplay experience, there's something oddly exhilarating about dodging invisible bullets and witnessing cows gracefully take flight to the heavens. It's a chaotic ballet that keeps you on your toes and reminds you that in the Wild West, anything is possible.

So, if you enjoy the thrill of uncertainty, the constant fear of encountering modder-induced madness, and the challenge of surviving in a lawless wasteland, then Red Dead Online might just be the game for you. Red Dead Online is waiting to whisk you away on a wild ride where the only limit is your imagination (and perhaps the occasional server crash)

Although I do enjoy the game, Rockstar has not finished bug testing it seems. Every single session has bugs which are an inconvenience and often times game-breaking. The moonshine shack for example, the doors just don't work sometimes. Your character will push against it as if its locked despite you literally owning the building. How to fix it? Go in to a new session and hope it stops. Sometimes entering from the other side of the shack helps but that could take several tries (and that assumes the game doesn't wait 30 seconds before letting you enter). Another common issue is server crashing. Ill be playing with my friends in the middle of a 5-star legendary bounty and boom, server is done for. That difficult mission we were in the middle of was a waste of time now. And its not just after bounties. Any mission has a chance, albeit small, to crash your game. For a game that looks and feels so beautiful and well put together its a shame that after several years Rockstar has no intention to fix what is so blatantly wrong. But above all else, we have cheaters. They destroy lobbies. Altering the map, causing all npcs and players to constantly die, griefing players, and more. Its not fun to be hunted down after starting an important (yes I know its a game) mission by a cheater who has no other purpose than to ruin the game for everyone else.

In conclusion, Rockstar is a greedy company that doesn't care about their game so long as it rakes in money, and their game has several prominent issues that need to be addressed/fixed.

The online version is fun, especially with friends, but sometimes it gets buggy and may crash. There is the occasional hacker that likes to mess around with mods, however I don't mind and just usually jump into a new session. The main story of your online character has some good missions, and I enjoy watching my character through the cut scenes. I would suggest--if someone is thinking about starting any new roles--to start with the collector first, then trader or bounty hunter. The moonshine role has some good side quests to gain xp--like the bar fighting lol--The naturalist role is my least favorite. That being said, you can use your trader role and naturalist role together to get legendary pelts to stock up your trader wagon. Just be aware that once you kill and skin the legendary animal, Harriet will be upset and will lock you out of missions for the next 30 min.

i have to say the online is mediocre, HOWEVER THE SINGLE PLAYER STORY IS PERHAPS ONE OF THE GREATEST GAMES OF ALL TIME IF NOT THE GREATEST. 

THE OPEN WORLD IS NEXT LEVEL. I DON'T CARE WHO YOU ARE, THERE IS TRULY NO ARGUMENT THAT THERE IS NO OPEN WORLD THAT HAS THIS GREAT OF DETAIL, STORY+SIDE MISSIONS+OPEN WORLD INTERTWINED SO WELL, NPC SOPHISTICATION, GRAPHICS, AND JUST EVERYTHING.

OTHER GAMES HAVE MUCH LARGER WORLDS, BUT DO THEY HAVE AS GREAT NPC AI? EVOLVING WORLD?

OTHER GAMES HAVE PERHAPS GREAT NPC AI, BUT AS BEAUTIFUL WORLD + STORY AT THE SAME TIME?

THIS IS TRULY A MARVEL FOR NOT JUST GAMING, BUT FOR ALL OF ENTERTAINMENT AND TECHNOLOGY IN MY OPINION. ROCKSTAR CONTINUES TO ASTOUND US WITH HOW MUCH WORK THEY PUT INTO THE GAMES. 

SO ALL OF YOU STOP CRITICIZING ROCKSTAR FOR HOW LONG THEY ARE TAKING. WOULD YOU RUSH MICHAELANGELO PAINTING THE SISTINE CHAPPEL?????????????????????? WOULD YOU RUSH DA VINCI WHEN HE WAS PAINTING THE MONA LISA? WOULD YOU RUSH MICHAEL JACKSON WHEN HE WAS WRITING THRILLER? HE DIED BY THE WAY DID ANYONE HEAR ABOUT THAT, YEAH MICHAEL JACKSON, THE FAMOUS POP SINGER PASSED AWAY. 

AT THE END OF THE DAY, THIS IS WITHOUT A DOUBT SINGLE PLAYER WISE, ONE OF THE GREATEST OPEN WORLDS EVER. IT'S LIKE 3 GAMES IN ONE. STORY, SIDE MISSIONS, AND FREE ROAM. YOU CAN GO HUNT, RANDOM EVENTS ALL OVER THE WORLD THAT FLOW FLAWLESSLY IN TERMS OF TRANSITIONS. YOU CAN EVEN LITERALLY CREATE YOUR OWN MISSION WITH THE AMOUNT OF FREE ROAM CONTENT THAT'S NOT STORY MISSIONS OR SIDE MISSIONS - ONE THING I WOULD DO IS GO OUT FIND NPC CABIN, CAMP OUT TIL NIGHT, THEN GO IN AND BURGLAR THE HOUSE. NPCS LITERALLY ARE SLEEPING AND YOU CAN KILL IN SLEEP, THEY CAN WAKE UP, GOD VARIOUS INTERACTIONS NOT JUST SOME RANDOM BUILDING FOR SHOW LIKE MUCH OF GTA 5. RDR2 REALLY FIXED THE INTERIORS, AND NOT JUST HAVING AN INTERIOR, BUT THE AMOUNT OF WHAT YOU CAN DO AND THE REACTIONS WITHIN THE INTERIORS - CATFISH JACKSONS AND ABERDEEEN PIG FARM ARE EXAMPLES.

OKAY. SO ALL I HAVE TO SAY SINGLE PLAYER WISE THIS IS WITHOUT DOUBT ONE OF THE GREATEST SINGLE PLAYER OPEN WORLD GAMES EVER,  LIKE YOU LITERALLY HAVE TO PLAY THIS ALL OF YOU. BUY THIS GAME IMMEDIATELY.

HOWEVER FOR ONLINE, PLAY IT IF YOU WANT. IMAGINE CLINT EASTWOOD NAKED

Howdy y'all! I've been gallivanting around in Red Dead Online and let me tell ya, it's like being a hog in a mud puddle - dirty but darn fun!

Sure, creating your character might make you feel like a goose with a broken wing, but once you saddle up and head out into the wild west, it's like being on an adventure with your best horse. The missions are as unpredictable as a lightning strike and rival outlaws are as cunning as a fox in a henhouse. And good golly, the dynamic weather system is like nothing you've ever seen before!

And don't even get me started on the online posse system - it's like having your own band of merry misfits to roam around with. The glitches and bugs may be more common than a tumbleweed in the desert, but it just adds to the excitement. So saddle up, partner, and give Red Dead Online a shot. Who knows, you might just enjoy it more than your grandma's apple pie!

[h1]Red Dead Online[/h1]
Red Dead Online is an awsome well made game set in 1899 and has many different features.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
✅ Multiplayer
✅ A variety of difficulties
✅ Simple Controls
✅ Fun gameplay
✅ Graphically Stunning

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
⛔️ Cheaters

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
The gameplay involves a lot of different elements. PvP, PvE and Roles are the main 3.

[h1]PvP:[/h1]
The PvP in red dead online is ok its just that hackers are quite common due to the anticheat in the game being terrible. Theres many different gamemodes you can play with friends or just random RDO lovers!

[h1]PvE:[/h1]
Theres plenty of missions where you are fighting npcs and blowing up stuff. But there is also many npcs around the map in general that you can fight or kill.

[h1]Roles:[/h1]
Bounty hunter, Naturalist, Moonshiner, Trader and collector are the 5 roles in the game. Moonshiner Costs 25 Gold (Plus The 15 Gold To Start Trader). Bounty Hunter Costs 15 Gold Bars (Plus Another 15 for Prestigious License). Trader costs 15 Gold as stated before and Naturalist costs 25 Gold.


In RDO its very common to encounter a cheater and sometimes can be quite frustrating but we will just have to wait for a new anticheat to stop these cheaters.


[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Overall Red Dead Online is a good fun game and has an engaging story and is fun to play with friends. But only because of cheaters/hackers your experience may not be as good, but if your ok with a couple cheaters every so often then I think this game would be perfect for you!

Yeehaw! Red Dead Online is the rootin' tootin'est wild west adventure this side of the Mississippi! The ginormous world out there is chock-full of risks and chances, and the gameplay is so immersive you'll forget you have a life outside of it. With so many activities and missions to choose from, you'll never be bored! Whether you're looking to join forces with fellow players to take down some pesky outlaws or venture out into the wild to hunt for elusive critters, there's always something exciting to discover. So saddle up, partner, and get ready for some rootin' tootin' fun! Wowza, these graphics are so stunning they make my eyes pop out like a cartoon character! And the attention to detail is so incredible, I feel like I'm in a microscopic world where every pixel has its own personality. Wow, even the pixels in this game have more life than my houseplants. The online community is like a big, warm hug from a friendly octopus. There are so many tentacles to help you out and join in on the silly shenanigans. Yeehaw! Red Dead Online is the rootinest, tootinest good time you'll ever have in the wild west. I reckon you'll love it if you're a fan of shootin', ridin', and livin' like a cowboy. Although there is quite a lot of cheaters which can get annoying

"Have you ever heard the tragedy of Red Dead Online?"
"No."
"I thought not. It's not a tale the cowboys would tell you. It's a gamer legend. Red Dead Online was a game so vast and immersive, players could ride across the Wild West and live a life of crime or heroism, forging their own path. It had such attention to detail, players could even form posses and go bounty hunting."

"They could actually... create their own story?"
"The open world of Red Dead Online is a gateway to many experiences... some consider to be extraordinary."
"Wh– What happened to it?"
"Well, as the game's popularity grew, the developers saw an opportunity to capitalize on its success. They started prioritizing monetization over enhancing the core experience. As a result, they introduced numerous microtransactions and paid content that provided little value to the players."

"Did that... ruin the game?"
"Over time, it did. As the developers became more focused on their greed for money, they neglected the essential aspects of the game and its community. Players began to lose interest, feeling that the game was becoming more of a cash grab than an immersive Wild West experience. The once thriving community started to dwindle, leaving behind a shell of what was once a remarkable game."

"Is there any hope for Red Dead Online?"
"Perhaps, but it would require the developers to refocus their priorities and work to rebuild the trust of the players. Only then could the game could become what it was always supposed to be."

[b]Almost unplayable due to cheat service buyers. Easily avoidable with anticheat if they bothered to get one worth anything.[/b]

[b]This is a neutral-positive review, I have just given it a thumbs down for issues explained below to urge Rockstar to actually do something about said issues. I have seen a lot of reviews that are truly negative, but thumbs ups. I don't think this is the right approach to get a massive company's attention.[/b] Beautiful graphics and rich content. This game is more engaging than any MMO I play. I really do recommend you buy it, only after reading the below disclaimer.

[b]For those looking to buy[/b]
Go in understanding Rockstar Games is notorious for having issues with hackers, and Red Dead II Online is no different. My best tip is playing in Defensive Mode (player menu \ online options \ playing style) which grants a huge PvP damage reduction (i.e. head shots only result in body shot damage instead of something like 500% damage), immunity from PvP melee, immunity from player dynamite, and immunity from PvP lasso. You cannot keep Defensive Mode if you attack first. Hackers can still burn you (may have been patched with dynamite), spawn enemy animals, and spawn developer(?) treasure chests that will get you banned if you loot them (never touch a chest with metal bands in free roam if you're paranoid like me). Rockstar cares about money, you will not be able to appeal an unfair ban like this. Despite what Rockstar advises, reporting cheaters/hackers is not the greatest idea: these malicious players use the account names of others and you'll likely not be able to stay still long enough to do so anyways. Instead, go to the main menu \ Online \ Free Roam, then rejoin free roam. If griefers are following you server to server, confirm you know everyone on your friends list via the player menu.
[b]Addon:[/b] Apparently hackers can also force you/your horse to wear [url=http://prntscr.com/21y1sxl]special items[/url]. The server swap trick still works in this case, swap servers immediately. This may or may not be my character after returning from AFK.

[b]Feedback[/b]
Rockstar, please:
(i) improve Defensive Mode to make defensive players immune to player dynamite and fires in free roam;
(ii) improve Defensive Mode or make a Passive Mode that wholly prevents griefing with other players, going as far as to prevent collision with them; and
(iii) have your folks spectating random lobbies in-game to catch cheaters/hackers. If you genuinely can't tell when a cheater/hacker is posing as another player, something is seriously wrong here.

[b]The game is also not the most friendly to genuinely new Red Dead players, and tutorials can take up to 30 hours of play time to appear in the game. However, plenty of fan tutorials exist on YouTube that are extremely helpful.[/b]

I hope you purchase this game regardless of the above issues, and if you own the game consider making a similar review. A bad review score is not great for Rockstar's income, and that may just be a catalyst for improvement.

Screw you rockstar for allowing this amazing game to die out in favor of GTA. Why even put in the money and effort to make such an amazing game if you're just going to abandon it. Bugs and glitches litter online play, not to mention that the game sees no more updates on content in the middle of story missions. Jobs get old fast. Stables sometimes don't work properly causing you to restart the whole client waiting long periods of times on a loading screens and Rockstart essentially abandoned the game to which ill get to in a moment. 

I'd be able to excuse ALL of these due to how fun the game is and I'd be able to recommend it if it weren't for the sleezy, crappy, and absolute degenerate of human beings that mod and hack the game TO SPECIFICALLY grief people. I've ran into nice modders who were jsut messing with some settings. Typically just watching everyone from the distance and even playing vigilantes to stop the bad modders from ruining everyone's fun but the bad CLEARLY outwiegh the good as you'll find sh*t happening as follows that keeps you from enjoying the game: 

-Exploding randomly
-Any pelts you collect explode randomly
-Spawning of infinite predators that mawl you
-Spawning things on top of you
-crashing your game (I'll get to this. This one is a kicker.) 
-Impersonating you and getting you reported. (They can do that. They can change their user name and frame you for modding)
- Obtaining your IP for your computer. (They dont have the mental capacity to actually do anything with it but some do. Your security is basically at risk.) 
-They can track you and follow you from server to server just to ruin your day. (This happened to me once. Mans had no life and took pleasure in my grief despite me not having had said a single word for about a day. 

And remember when I said they can crash your computer? Well you're gonna love this. They can do it voluntarily and can program it so that when you REPORT them for cheating and griefing, your computer crashes and they get notified of who reported them. The nice modders I ran into explained this to me and I was in utter shock. Rockstar let this go on for quite a while and did nothing to fix it. Reporting them only paints a target on your back.
